Andy L (Apple)

Find and replace thread üßµ

üîç Tyler F (Apple), David J (Apple), Anna K (Apple), Cole B (Apple), Bino G (Apple), Anant J (Apple), Louis B (Apple), Ali
‚úÖ James M (Apple)
Chang
2022-06-07 19:10:26

*Thread Reply:* Does UIFindInteraction work with custom stuff like handwriting?

Tyler
2022-06-07 19:10:50

*Thread Reply:* Hi! WKWebView and text view were mentioned, but what about cases in which recycled views are used? UICollectionView?

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:11:53

*Thread Reply:* UIFindInteraction is build to work with your custom views and with multiple views across you app. It is integrated in UIKit‚Äôs text views but you can adopt it for pretty much every view.

üëç Tyler, Chang, James M (Apple), Steve
Matt Z (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:12:25

*Thread Reply:* More information on UIFindInteraction can be learned in the session Adopt desktop class editing interactions.

Apple Developer
Adopt desktop class editing interactions - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover advanced desktop class editing features that can help people accelerate their productivity in your app. Learn how you can...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10071/
Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:12:28

*Thread Reply:* You can use UIFindInteraction with handwriting, but you‚Äôll need to convert the handwriting to strings yourself, perhaps using one of our ML frameworks!

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:18:26

*Thread Reply:* > Does UIFindInteraction work with custom stuff like handwriting? Echoing what Russell said. You can make this work with handwriting as long as you can convert the drawing to a string first, then provide results to the find interaction.

üëç Chang
James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:19:05

*Thread Reply:* > Hi! WKWebView and text view were mentioned, but what about cases in which recycled views are used? UICollectionView? Yes, UIFindInteraction works well with UICollectionView. As long as your "searchable object" is your model, you can provide results that represent ranges in your model, and when we ask you to decorate these results, you can do so when configuring the cells via content configurations, reloading using diffable data source if necessary.

Tyler
2022-06-07 19:23:33

*Thread Reply:* Are content configurations and diffable data source a requirement?

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:26:32

*Thread Reply:* Nope, that was just a recommendation. You can also decorate cells using collectionView:cellForItem, just remember what range we asked you to decorate, and take that into consideration in your data source methods.

Vince
2022-06-08 01:45:52

*Thread Reply:* If we support UITextInput in our custom view (and use UITextInteraction for selection, etc.), can we utilize UIFindInteraction?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:47:56

*Thread Reply:* Yes!

üëç James M (Apple)
James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 02:02:26

*Thread Reply:* Indeed! UIFindInteraction is designed to work well with classes that adopt UITextInput. Take a look at UITextSearchingFindSession and UITextSearching, or watch my session called "Adopt Desktop-class Editing Interactions".

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:09:45

Chang
2022-06-07 19:11:59

*Thread Reply:* It seems like iOS 16 requires user permission every time the UIPasteboard is accessed. Is there a way for the user to give permission once? This behavior breaks clipboard monitoring.

üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Yi-Shan
Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:13:04

*Thread Reply:* That is not possible. If you use system provided paste buttons you will not get the notification but if you programmatically access the pasteboard you can not hide this alert.

Oliver
2022-06-07 19:13:57

*Thread Reply:* Q: is this alert shown every time or once for an app/session?

Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:14:06

*Thread Reply:* Using UIPasteControl will avoid the permission alert

Chang
2022-06-07 19:15:09

*Thread Reply:* Are there any documentation for UIPasteControl? Or will it be mentioned in other sessions?

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:15:31

*Thread Reply:* > is this alert shown every time or once for an app/session? it depends on the pasteboard content. If there is new content, the alert shows up again.

Oliver
2022-06-07 19:17:02

*Thread Reply:* Every time? Uh, after watching the video, I was hoping it‚Äôll be like a notification request permission being persisted per app and changeable via settings. This will then indeed break a lot of ‚Äúconverting‚Äù tools‚Ä¶

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:17:36

*Thread Reply:* UIPasteControl is discussed at the 12min mark and we just made a thread for it https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H9K1JYJY/p1654622177855459

Materials in sidebar thread üßµ

üòÆ Tyler F (Apple), Louis B (Apple), Nico, Bino G (Apple), Anant J (Apple), Russell L (Apple), Dima G (Apple)
Jordan
2022-06-07 19:13:29

*Thread Reply:* To confirm, should we no longer set a background color of the sidebar collection view?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:14:50

*Thread Reply:* No you should still set a background color! If you use one of the system colors, like UIColor.systemBackgroundColor, UIKit automatically converts that into an equivalent material. All of the system colors have material equivalents.

üëç Kurt, Bino G (Apple)

Andy L (Apple)

üìã UIPasteControl thread üßµ

‚úÖ Russell L (Apple), Dima G (Apple), Maciej
üëç Ruslan, Matt Z (Apple), Jakub
ü§© Matt Z (Apple), Louis B (Apple)
üîí Matt Z (Apple), Anant J (Apple), Glen L (Apple), Chang, Anna K (Apple), Bino G (Apple)
Chang
2022-06-07 19:17:40

*Thread Reply:* Can I put UIPasteControl into a UIMenu?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:19:40

*Thread Reply:* You can't embed UIPasteControl into a UIMenu, but any UICommand using the paste: selector or UIAction with UIActionPaste will make a menu item that avoids the paste alert, just like UIPasteControl does.

üëå Maciej
Cole B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:20:11

*Thread Reply:* You can find the paste UIActionIdentifiers to avoid the paste alert here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiactionidentifier

Chang
2022-06-07 19:21:23

*Thread Reply:* Does UIActionIdentifier work with the new UIEditMenuInteraction?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:23:12

*Thread Reply:* Yes, if you have an action with one of the blessed identifiers listed above, it work with UIEditMenuInteraction.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:23:50

*Thread Reply:* UIEditMenuInteraction is based on the UIMenu and UIMenuElement infrastructure, so anything that works in menus should work with edit interaction

Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:41:46

*Thread Reply:* @Chang to answer your previous question https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uipastecontrol

üëç Chang
Greg
2022-06-08 00:00:02

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible to configure the font?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:03:38

*Thread Reply:* At the moment, UIPasteControl will use the system font from the device text size. If you need further customization, please file a FBA. Do note we intentionally limit what can be configured to ensure security, so arbitrary and/or developer fonts will not be possible.

Greg
2022-06-08 00:08:41

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a shame, but understandable for security I guess. We have a paste button on our UI and really want to avoid this system alert, but we use a custom font so the button will stand out with the system font. Is it worth filling a radar or is that just not possible for security?

Currently has a custom font and transparent with camera in background.

Image from iOS
Greg
2022-06-08 00:08:58

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for the quick answer too

üìú Improved sheets thread üßµ

üôå Bino G (Apple), Louis B (Apple), Dima G (Apple), Jakub, Oscar, Maximilian, Avery V (Apple)
ü§© Tyler F (Apple), Anna K (Apple), Marian G (Apple), Ruslan, Louis B (Apple), Jakub

2022-06-07 19:17:40

*Thread Reply:* This is amazing

‚ù§Ô∏è Russell L (Apple), Bruce N (Apple), Louis B (Apple)
Tyler
2022-06-07 19:17:54

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible to adjust the detent height dynamically? For example, after content is loaded?

üëç Russell L (Apple)
Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:18:04

*Thread Reply:* Yes!

üëç Tyler, Ruslan
üëè Chen-Yu, Anna K (Apple)
Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:19:18

*Thread Reply:* Not shown in the slide, you can call invalidateDetents on the UISheetPresentationController to cause your custom detents to be re-evaluated at any time. And you can call that inside sheet.animateChanges { } to animate it.

üôå Tyler, Bino G (Apple), Denis, Tomas, Maciej
Jason
2022-06-07 19:41:09

*Thread Reply:* Is there a "size to fit" type of detent, where you can set up constraints and the sheet will fit the content automatically?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:48:20

*Thread Reply:* There‚Äôs not. The sheet needs to know the detent height before the sheet content is in the view hierarchy, which also makes it difficult to measure the size of the content except in very simple cases. I welcome feedback reports if this is a use case that‚Äôs important to you üôÇ

üëç Jason
Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:18:51

Apple Developer
SF Symbols - Apple Developer
With over 4,000 symbols, SF Symbols is a library of iconography designed to integrate seamlessly with San Francisco, the system font for Apple platforms.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/sf-symbols/
üôå Jakub
Oliver
2022-06-07 19:24:52

*Thread Reply:* I have one wish though: tooling around custom SF Symbols. Currently we can only add monochrome but the other ‚Äúvariations‚Äù cannot be created on our own, right?

Matt Z (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:26:55

*Thread Reply:* There‚Äôs more information in What‚Äôs new in SF Symbols 4 that might help you author custom symbols

Apple Developer
What's new in SF Symbols 4 - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Explore the latest updates to SF Symbols, Apple's extensive library of iconography designed to integrate seamlessly with San Francisco,...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10157
Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:27:13

*Thread Reply:* They can be configured in the SF Symbols app! The app lets you define which layers in your symbol belong to each hierarchical/palette layer (as well as other fun things like what colors the symbol uses in multicolor mode). Then you can export the symbol with that information included.

You can try it out by cloning one of the built-in symbols as a custom symbol üôÇ

üëç Matt Z (Apple), Oliver
üéØ Matt Z (Apple)
Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:29:23

*Thread Reply:* You can also learn more with one of our talks from last year: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10288/

Apple Developer
Explore the SF Symbols 3 app - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Tour the latest updates to the SF Symbols app ‚Äî our interactive library for iconography. Learn how you can use the library to design...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10288/
Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:19:59

*Thread Reply:* (Looks like the SF Symbols 4 app is up now!)

Matthew
2022-06-10 09:20:42

*Thread Reply:* Are there any restrictions around SF Symbols in your App? i.e. could you use them as images in a game?

Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-10 15:43:04

*Thread Reply:* Ideally they should be displayed in a UIImageView. If you need to display them outside an image view, you could draw the image directly with UIImage‚Äôs drawInRect family of methods

2022-06-07 19:24:58

üíê Marian G (Apple), Bino G (Apple), Sven T (Apple), Dima G (Apple), Russell L (Apple), Avery V (Apple)
Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:26:46

*Thread Reply:* Mentioned in the deprecation notices, but not the video, you should attempt to access UIScreen instances through context: view.window.screen or view.window.windowScene.screen

üëç Anna K (Apple)
Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:27:47

*Thread Reply:* Also note that UIScreen.main is marked as API_TO_BE_DEPRECATED, which means we will explicitly deprecate it in the future.

üôå Kurt
Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:29:28

*Thread Reply:* We know there are a ton of uses of UIScreen.main out there. But as mentioned, it isn't safe to assume things will be on the main screen anymore. Make sure that new code does not reference this, and refactor existing code when possible

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:29:49

*Thread Reply:* If you do the work to be multi-scene aware, then you're probably on the right track!

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:36:56

*Thread Reply:* Re multiple screens, what's the recommendation for when you need the screen scale outside of the context of a view? Like when caching prepared UIImages for use across the app (and now potentially on multiple screens)

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:45:18

*Thread Reply:* In general we would recommend that you try and get a real trait collection or scale from the actual target (view, etc.) where the image is going to end up eventually.

üëç Anil Abraham
Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:45:37

*Thread Reply:* Then you can take that info into your background thread to use it to do processing

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:48:57

*Thread Reply:* So when there are multiple screens connected with different scales, would it make sense to just use the greatest scale? That negates some of the benefit of preparing the image at the right scale, but it's the best workaround I can come up with

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:50:03

*Thread Reply:* Can you go into more of the use case here? Is there a reason why you wouldn't know where this image will end up?

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:53:26

*Thread Reply:* In a social media app, I have a cache of prepared images for user avatars‚Äîsince they tend to be fairly large and are displayed frequently, I want to prepare them once and share them across the app. If my app were to have windows on both the builtin display of an iPad at 2x scale and an external display at 1x, I want to make sure I'm using the right scale for computing the pixel size for thumbnail preparation

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:53:53

*Thread Reply:* Each time the image is requested I know where it's going to end up, but I want to avoid the duplicate work of preparing the same image at multiple scales

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:55:39

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the context.

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:56:06

*Thread Reply:* This might be worth signing up for a lab to talk through a bit more with someone on the team

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:56:31

*Thread Reply:* Will do, thanks!

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:57:13

*Thread Reply:* Using the highest scale could definitely work, but there are other things that might be different between the displays, like gamut

üëç Anil Abraham
Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:24:25

ü§Ø Self-resizing cells thread üßµ

ü§Ø Tyler F (Apple), Sven T (Apple), Bino G (Apple), Lee, Louis B (Apple), Cole B (Apple), Sara F (Apple), Oscar, Leonard
‚ù§Ô∏è Bino G (Apple), Michael O (Apple), Oscar, Felix, Darshan
ü¶Ñ Marian G (Apple)
üéâ Michael, Marian G (Apple), Anna K (Apple), Dima G (Apple), Sara F (Apple)
üëÄ Zheming
Tyler
2022-06-07 19:25:09

*Thread Reply:* I assume this feature requires that we're using estimated, self-sizing cells?

Tyler
2022-06-07 19:25:44

*Thread Reply:* ah, maybe it depends on the options he's talking about?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:26:06

*Thread Reply:* Yes, that‚Äôs the idea: self-sizing cells can now directly request to be resized

Michael
2022-06-07 19:29:57

*Thread Reply:* Will be interesting to consider how to use these capabilities, if at all, for apps that support OS versions < 16. ü§î

‚òùÔ∏è Morten
Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:37:00

*Thread Reply:* On iOS 15 and earlier, you request an update to the size of self-sizing cells in UICollectionView and UITableView by: ‚Ä¢ If using diffable data source, re-applying the diffable data source‚Äôs current snapshot with animatingDifferences: true ‚Ä¢ If not using diffable data source, performing empty batch updates on the collection or table view directly Don‚Äôt forget on iOS 15, you can use the reconfigure APIs to also update content in the cell too ‚Äî if the cell needs to be resized that will always happen automatically after you reconfigure it.

The new selfSizingInvalidation feature in iOS 16 makes it much easier for cells to directly request a size update, without needing to worry about going to the diffable data source or UICollectionView/UITableView!

üôå Leonard
üëç Michael
‚ù§Ô∏è Stephen
Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:26:45

üåà ‚ù§Ô∏è :swift_blue: UIKit & SwiftUI thread üßµ

:swift_orange: Tyler F (Apple), Bino G (Apple), Chang, Oscar, Kaitlyn, Louis B (Apple), Anna K (Apple)
:swift_blue: Dima G (Apple), Tyler F (Apple), Oscar, Kaitlyn, David J (Apple), Anna K (Apple)
üí∏ Tyler F (Apple)
üôå Marian G (Apple), Jamie M (Apple)
üëÄ Rafaela
Austin
2022-06-07 19:28:15

*Thread Reply:* Not sure if this can be answered, but in past releases have UIKit advancements been used as the foundation underneath new SwiftUI APIs?

Jason
2022-06-07 19:29:47

*Thread Reply:* I would presume so, last year's UISheetPresentationController for half-sheets is likely powering the presentationDetents modifier

üëç Russell L (Apple), Bino G (Apple), Dima G (Apple)
Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:31:00

*Thread Reply:* It depends on the features. For example a lot of the desktop class app features are implemented in UIKit and exposed with a more declarative API that fits SwiftUI better there. The goal is to have the best experience in both frameworks.

üëç Austin, Jason, Denis
üëã Adrian

Is that something that‚Äôs expected to work, or not yet?

Use the lightning bolt :workflowbolt: icon at the lower left and select UIFrameworks - Ask a Question Your question will be delivered directly to the UIKit team, and we‚Äôll repost and answer as many of them as we can.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:32:56

@Chang asked > Was something changed on UIDragInteraction? When I tried doing local drag and drop (move) in my app, the drop gets cancelled if my finger is not perfectly still when I lift it. Bug?

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:33:18

*Thread Reply:* That may be bug. Feel free to file a feedback and join a UIFrameworks lab where we can look into this together!

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:34:21

*Thread Reply:* It would also be interesting to know if you have any conflicting gesture recognizers. If you do have any other gesture recognizers attached, I would suggest disabling all of them and enabling them one at a time to see which one is causing the conflict.

Chang
2022-06-07 19:35:28

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a very good suggestion @James M (Apple)! I have a soup of gesture recognizers. Might be a UISwipeGR!

Chang
2022-06-07 19:37:51

*Thread Reply:* Any chance we can lower the duration of the lift gesture (without doing some ugly hacks)?

Chang
2022-06-07 19:38:08

*Thread Reply:* I know the duration is reduced if it‚Äôs dragged with a pointer.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:35:44

@Anil Abraham asked > Does the browser-style navigation bar/controller manage the forward navigation stack automatically, and if so, is it accessible for, say, a custom swipe forward gesture a la Safari?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:36:42

*Thread Reply:* The browser mode doesn‚Äôt manage a forward navigation stack, so you‚Äôll have to bring your own implementation (and a gesture if you like).

üëç Anil Abraham
David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:37:54

*Thread Reply:* It may also be more flexible to bring your own back/forward stack for this case, as if your app adapts to compact modes you may want to fallback to a more traditional navigation style (the navigation bar will do so automatically)

üíØ Anil Abraham
Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:39:27

*Thread Reply:* Looking at the UINavigationItem docs, I see there's a new backAction property but there's not a corresponding one for going forwards. So is the forwards button itself something I'd also need to add myself?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:53:34

*Thread Reply:* typically for forward/backward navigation we would recommend using UIBarButtonItems for that (in the leading position)

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:54:06

*Thread Reply:* the backAction gets translated slightly differently, and would (in browser mode) produce a typical back button rather than what you likely want for ‚Äúgo back‚Äù in the browsing stack

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:54:57

*Thread Reply:* its certainly a subtlety here, but this is what Files does and what we would probably say is best

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:55:46

*Thread Reply:* I see. So putting my own bar button item in the leading position would place it after the builtin back button but before the title

Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 19:56:07

*Thread Reply:* And to match the appearance, it seems like the back button is just using the chevron.left SF symbol in the default size/config

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:00:32

*Thread Reply:* the default is chevron.backward (which is left in LTR). If you specify this as the image for a UIBarButtonItem UIKit will supply the proper symbol config to match

David D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:02:04

*Thread Reply:* so to sum up, to get File‚Äôs style, set 2 items with chevron.backward & chevron.forward and manage your own stack (replacing content as necessary). Then you can reorganize when in compact to a more traditional UI

‚ù§Ô∏è Anil Abraham
Anil Abraham
2022-06-07 20:04:12

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, thank you!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:40:28

@Jordan asked > Thanks for the great session! Love UIKit so much. In a UIKit app if you enable Mac Catalyst with the Mac idiom, is it possible to opt into native macOS SwiftUI? By default it uses the iOS style for Form for example which isn't ideal when you're building UI that'll only be used in your Mac app. Thanks!

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:40:42

*Thread Reply:* No, you can either use SwiftUI in native macOS (AppKit) mode, or Catalyst (UIKit) mode, but not both.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:50:42

@Adrian asked > We'd like to improve our app & framework to have a better desktop-class experience. For that, we'd like to utilize UIContextMenuInteraction and the new UIEditMenuInteraction. How should we decide where to use one or the other? Can context menus on iPadOS be presented "in place", like on macOS, without a targeted preview?

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:51:09

*Thread Reply:* UIEditMenuInteraction powers the new light-weight edit menu. With edit menu interaction, on right-click on iPadOS (and macOS), it‚Äôll also automatically present the more compact context menu without a targeted preview. Use Edit menu interaction in contexts where you don‚Äôt need a preview, or where the menu shouldn‚Äôt block the content (i.e. text, or some canvas type view like Keynote).

üôå Adrian
Adrian
2022-06-07 19:54:55

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! If I understand correctly, would you recommend using Edit menu to present actions for inserting objects onto a canvas like in Keynote (after a long press or a right click), because a context menu would block the content?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:56:52

*Thread Reply:* UIEditMenuInteraction also has an arrow you can point at something, unlike UIContextMenuInteraction.

üôá Adrian
Adrian
2022-06-07 20:03:52

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, Glen! And from what I‚Äôve seen so far, Edit menu can be triggered programmatically as a result of a user action or custom gesture. To make sure: can context menus be triggered in that way as well?

Adrian
2022-06-07 20:17:23

*Thread Reply:* Anyway, thank you both for taking the time to answer my question!

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:12:59

*Thread Reply:* We do not allow for programmatic activation of context menus, and only for the lightweight edit menu.

üëç Adrian
Adrian
2022-06-07 21:13:57

*Thread Reply:* Got it. Thank you for clarifying this!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:51:29

@Ratnesh asked > In iOS 15, compositional layout with orthogonal scrolling behaviour with a single section in non-full screen size also scrolls vertically, what is the correct way to prevent vertical scrolling for single horizontal section?

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:51:39

*Thread Reply:* If it is the outer (collection) view that is scrolling, you can set alwaysBounceVertical = false on it to prevent the scrolling. However if it is just a single section you may be better of not using an orthogonal section but just a horizontally scrolling collection view. This might be a great question to discuss in the labs later this week to find a solution that works best for you.

Ratnesh
2022-06-07 19:53:33

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, other solution we tried to go back with the flow layout but we then loose the nice things about the declarative relation as in compositional layout.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:51:46

@Ratnesh asked > In new UICalendarView, is it possible to change the layout? Like in the iOS Calender app?

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:52:32

*Thread Reply:* That isn‚Äôt possible at the moment. Please file a feedback for us if this is something you‚Äôd like to see us add in the future.

Ratnesh
2022-06-07 19:55:40

*Thread Reply:* Sure, thanks.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:54:54

@Rens asked > Since setValue:forKey: on UIDevice is not longer supported to force orientation. Is there are step by step explanation of how to force landscape orientation for 1 UIViewController only?

Chris D (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:56:07

*Thread Reply:* You can call +[UIViewController attemptRotationToDeviceOrientation] and return an updated UIInterfaceOrientationMask from -[UIViewController supportedInterfaceOrientations].

üëç Rens
Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:57:59

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs also important to note that setValue:forKey: to access and modify internal state is never a supported way to do things. You might get lucky but you should really consider this as not being supported and should file feedback to request API for the feature you are trying to access.

üëÜ Bino G (Apple), Kurt
Rens
2022-06-07 20:01:10

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, I somehow missed attemptRotationToDeviceOrientation so I‚Äôm going to give it a try in a sample project. If that doesn‚Äôt work i‚Äôm going to see if I can join a lab.

I‚Äôve always avoided using setValue:forKey: but a client was stubborn and demanded a fullscreen button that turned the orientation so I had too.

But thanks I‚Äôm going to give it a try üôÇ

Kai
2022-06-09 10:07:49

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Rens we have also such a button and the same problem now. After the button press we support that the user can rotate back with a physical orientation change. It's not a nice solution in my opinion, but it seems to work to temporarily override supportedInterfaceOrientation, call attemptRotationToDeviceOrientation() and then reset supportedInterfaceOrientation to all normally allowed orientations again.

I started making a prototype here. Maybe it's useful for you too.

Rotate.zip
Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:59:48

üôÇ Matt Z (Apple)
Nikhil
2022-06-07 22:13:26

*Thread Reply:* I was hoping to find an eraser or other drawing tools in the symbols, but didn't find it in the new beta. I can draw my own - wondering if anyone has a recommendation for which app is best for making SVGs. Pixelmator seems to output bad SVGs in my experience. Photoshop has an SVG exporter, but it's only present on Intel builds of Photoshop.

Matt Z (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:27:07

*Thread Reply:* Those are some great tools. It‚Äôs unfortunate that they aren‚Äôt working for you, though. I‚Äôd recommend reaching out to the developer of those apps for assistance with SVGs.

The design team likes to support Photoshop, XD, Sketch, and Keynote in their workflow as shown in the Apple Design Resources. There are a lot of other great vector editing tools on the Mac App Store, too.

In a pinch, you could even edit the SVG file manually since it is just XML and can be edited as plain text. I‚Äôve personally done this for a few small changes when I didn‚Äôt yet have my usual go-to design tools installed.

Chris D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:23:23

You‚Äôll be very able to make great UIs with variable symbols! üßµ

Jeff M (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:53:28

*Thread Reply:* Row height estimation only applies to NSTableViews whose delegate implements heightOfRow. Auto-layout based rows will work as before.

As for question #2, assuming I understand it correctly, a given row will be the same height no matter how many columns it has.

Brendan
2022-06-07 20:59:13

*Thread Reply:* I was referring to the row height taking on the size of the largest cell. Not different row heights per cell. In a row I might have a bunch of columns. Some with small amounts of text and some with large amounts of text. I‚Äôd want the row height to take on the height of the cell with the largest amount of content.

Brendan
2022-06-07 21:00:09

*Thread Reply:* And when you resized the columns, the row heights would adjust to size to the cell with the largest amount of content again.

Brendan
2022-06-07 21:01:24

*Thread Reply:* Just like in Numbers

image.png
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:36:56

@Saurabh asked > The session mentioned NSWindow.collectionBehavior, but how will Stage Manager interact with NSWindow.level? More specifically, if I have a window in my app that I globally float above all other windows by setting the level to NSWindow.Level.screenSaver, will that window still appear in Stage Manager?

Jeff N (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:39:12

*Thread Reply:* Window levels still work the same way in Stage Manager, in that they‚Äôll impact the z-ordering of your window with respect to other windows on screen. Otherwise, its relationship to other windows in center stage (like whether it‚Äôs considered ‚Äúfloating‚Äù or ‚Äúauxiliary‚Äù) is dictated by its collection behavior.

üéØ Matt Z (Apple)
üôè Saurabh
Saurabh
2022-06-07 20:44:07

*Thread Reply:* Thank you Jeff!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:44:44

@Brian asked > If I have an app that's primarily written in AppKit, is there any way to use SwiftUI to define toolbar items from within an AppKit window? Or does the window itself need to be created by SwiftUI too for that to work?

Chris D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:45:41

*Thread Reply:* You can attach your own NSView hierarchies to NSToolbarItems. Within these, you can use the NSHostingController or NSHostView classes offered by SwiftUI to embed a SwiftUI view hierarchy in an AppKit view hierarchy.

Jeff N (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:47:03

*Thread Reply:* It is correct that the SwiftUI .toolbar() modifier only works with windows that are created and managed by SwiftUI. But, as Chris said, you can bring SwiftUI content into your NSToolbar using a hosting view.

Brian
2022-06-07 20:48:34

*Thread Reply:* Got it, thanks!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:48:09

@Saurabh asked > Assuming I am not doing anything custom or low-level involving Metal, are there any AppKit-specific APIs to be aware of to fully support ProMotion displays?

Chris D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:48:31

*Thread Reply:* macOS 12 added these new APIs to NSScreen. ```// Variable Rate Refresh @interface NSScreen ()

/** The maximum frames per second this screen supports. **/ @property (readonly) NSInteger maximumFramesPerSecond API_AVAILABLE(macos(12.0));

/** The minimum refresh interval this screen supports, in seconds.

This is the shortest amount of time a frame will be present on screen.
minimumRefreshInterval and maximumRefreshInterval will be the same for displays that do not support variable refresh rates.

**/ @property (readonly) NSTimeInterval minimumRefreshInterval API_AVAILABLE(macos(12.0));

/** The maximum refresh interval this screen supports, in seconds.

minimumRefreshInterval and maximumRefreshInterval will be the same for displays that do not support variable refresh rates.

**/ @property (readonly) NSTimeInterval maximumRefreshInterval API_AVAILABLE(macos(12.0));

/** The update granularity of the screen's current mode, in seconds.

The display will update at the next boundary defined by the granularity, after the minimum refresh interval has been reached. When 0, the display can update at any time between the minimum and maximum refresh rate intervals of the screen. Fixed refresh rate screen modes will return the refresh interval as the update granularity (e.g. 16.66ms for 60Hz refresh rates), meaning updates only occur at refresh rate boundaries.

**/ @property (readonly) NSTimeInterval displayUpdateGranularity API_AVAILABLE(macos(12.0));

/** The time at which the last framebuffer update occurred on the display, in seconds since startup that the system has been awake. **/ @property (readonly) NSTimeInterval lastDisplayUpdateTimestamp API_AVAILABLE(macos(12.0));

@end```

Chris D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:48:48

*Thread Reply:* If you are managing your own refresh timer, these can be helpful.

üôå Saurabh
Chris D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:49:13

*Thread Reply:* But if you‚Äôre just doing normal AppKit stuff, you don‚Äôt need to take any action. NSAnimation functionality, for example, will ‚Äúdo the right thing.‚Äù

üôå Saurabh

Jeff M (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:55:46

*Thread Reply:* Row height estimation as discussed in the session only apply to NSTableViews whose delegate implements heightOfRow. Auto-layout based rows will continue work as before.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:08:06

@Simon asked > Is there a way to present the menu of a UIEditMenuInteraction that‚Äôs associated with an instance of UITextInput? I‚Äôm working on a text editor where I‚Äôm programmatically showing the menu. Previously I could use UIMenuController.shared.showMenu(from:rect:). What‚Äôs the equivalent with UIEditMenuInteraction to show a menu with all the standard editing actions?

üëÄ James M (Apple), Adrian
James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:08:53

*Thread Reply:* Yep, UIEditMenuInteraction has a method called presentEditMenu(with:configuration), which can be used in the same way.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:10:21

*Thread Reply:* The default menu will contain the standard edit actions. You can override the menu if you'd like via menuForConfiguration on UIEditMenuInteractionDelegate.

Simon
2022-06-07 21:14:00

*Thread Reply:* @James M (Apple) Thanks for your replies.

I tried grabbing the UIEditMenuInteraction from UITextInput‚Äôs interactions and present it with presentEditMenu(with:) . However, I‚Äôll need to pass a configuration with an ID. When supplying nil as ID, the menu isn‚Äôt shown because it doesn‚Äôt have any command and/or actions.

If I pass UITextSelectionView.SelectionCommands as ID it works but that feels a bit wrong. I‚Äôve only gotten this ID by happenstance because my console showed some errors earlier.

Simon
2022-06-07 21:14:53

*Thread Reply:* Is this the recommended way of doing it?

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:20:29

*Thread Reply:* You should install your own UIEditMenuInteraction; if nothing is showing when you call presentEditMenu(with:) , then there‚Äôs a good chance that nothing is responding YES to canPerformAction:withSender: so I‚Äôd verify that your actions can be performed.

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:23:22

*Thread Reply:* Also, if you just want to add/remove/change some menu items for the edit menu that comes up on a UITextInput like text view etc., you can override buildMenuWithBuilder: on any suitable view controller in your hierarchy and use UIMenuBuilder to change the menu.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:21:45

@Adrian asked > Is the new UIHostingConfiguration bound only to collection and table view cells? Or is this API designed to be used in other places where I might "inject" SwiftUI views in the middle of custom UIKit view hierarchies?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:22:09

*Thread Reply:* UIHostingConfiguration is designed to be used with UICollectionView and UITableView cells. Watch the video ‚ÄúUse SwiftUI with UIKit‚Äù coming on Thursday later this week to learn more about it, and other ways to integrate SwiftUI into your UIKit app! https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072

Apple Developer
Use SwiftUI with UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how to take advantage of the power of SwiftUI in your UIKit app. Build custom UICollectionView and UITableView cells seamlessly...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072
üôå Adrian, Dima G (Apple), Chen-Yu, Jordan
üôå:skin_tone_2: Sara F (Apple)
Adrian
2022-06-07 21:28:23

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! So if I‚Äôm vending a mostly UIKit-based framework and I want my users to be able to customize/replace a part of the hierarchy with SwiftUI, embedding a child UIHostingController continues to be the most recommended way to support this? UIHostingController looked to be a much better fit‚Ä¶ üòÑ

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:37:56

*Thread Reply:* UIHostingController is the most general-purpose API to embed SwiftUI inside your UIKit app. Because it is a view controller, you can use it anywhere you can present or embed a view controller in UIKit, and all SwiftUI features are supported inside of it (including ones that require a connection to the view controller hierarchy in UIKit). UIHostingController also has some new features in iOS 16, so be sure to watch the ‚ÄúUse SwiftUI with UIKit‚Äù video to learn more about all of this later this week.

Adrian
2022-06-07 21:40:48

*Thread Reply:* Noted, I‚Äôll be sure to do so. Thanks again for answering my questions!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:26:18

@Brendan asked > Most SF Symbols appear to have transparent background colours. In AppKit, is there a way to get a white background colour so that coloured symbols look good on NSPopupButtons? Right now when the selection is hovering over an NSMenuItem with a coloured SF Symbol for the image, the symbol colour doesn't change to make it viewable. For example, if your accent colour is yellow and the NSMenuItem's image is yellow, it basically disappears from view (yellow on yellow).

Jeff N (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:28:43

*Thread Reply:* In general, we don‚Äôt alter color images for states like menu highlight, because your image might be something like an icon which doesn‚Äôt make sense to draw with a white foreground.

However, I think your SF Symbol example is a good case where we could be smarter, since we know more about the underlying symbol image. That would be an excellent enhancement request for us.

üëç Matt Z (Apple), Brendan
Brendan
2022-06-07 21:32:40

*Thread Reply:* Excellent. I‚Äôll submit feedback for it. When setting to multi-coloured SF Symbols, NSPopupButton just completely removes all the colours. But explicitly setting colours for them using pallet configuration does show the colours, but doesn‚Äôt invert or change the highlight state when traversing the popup button.

Brendan
2022-06-07 21:34:03

*Thread Reply:* Here‚Äôs my popup button example with SF Symbols.

image.png
Brendan
2022-06-07 21:34:27

*Thread Reply:* None

image.png
Matt Z (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:46:29

*Thread Reply:* NSMenu does have a delegation mechanism that can tell you when an item has been highlighted. Try implementing -menu:willHighlightItem:, and altering the highlighted item. Since these are symbols, you could use -[NSImage imageWithSymbolConfiguration:] to get a new image with a different configuration, and set that to the highlighted item‚Äôs image property. Just be sure to restore the original image back to the previously-highlighted menu item and when the menu closes (-menuDidClose:).

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:30:42

@Ratnesh asked > Is it possible to access swiftui environment/modifiers inside UIViewRepresentables?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:31:07

*Thread Reply:* Yes. The context passed to make/updateUIView(context:) has an environment property you can read from.

https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/uiviewrepresentable/makeuiview(context:)

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:32:00

*Thread Reply:* Or you can use @Environment in your representable struct.

Ratnesh
2022-06-07 21:40:19

*Thread Reply:* Thanks üòä

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:31:57

@Amy asked > Is there a known issue with keyboard shortcuts in UITextView where if you type command-B then press ‚ÄòB‚Äô straight after, the ‚ÄòB‚Äô key press is not registered? (It‚Äôs when the keystroke is the same letter as the previous command key combination.) > > I thought it was our bug originally, but haven‚Äôt made any headway into what‚Äôs causing it.

Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:33:07

*Thread Reply:* Is this a new issue in iOS 16? Are you able to reproduce this in a sample app? This is not a known issue at the moment

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:33:34

*Thread Reply:* Are you still holding the command key on the second 'B' press?

Amy
2022-06-07 21:34:23

*Thread Reply:* This is an issue in iOS 15 (not tried in 16). Definitely not still holding command.

Sample app is our next step, although we hit it in two apps so far (but with some shared code so the bug could be in there).

Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:38:26

*Thread Reply:* Unfortunately I‚Äôm not able to reproduce this in a UITextView with allowsEditingTextAttributes enabled. Hitting ‚åòB toggles boldface on the selected text, then hitting B replaces the now-bold text into a ‚Äúb‚Äù.

Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:38:46

*Thread Reply:* If you‚Äôre able to reproduce this in a sample app, and file a bug report with the report attached (and post the report here), that would help us investigate the issue further!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:34:34

@Chang asked > What should I do when I encounter performance issue when I have hundreds of CAShapeLayers (ink strokes) inside a huge UIScrollView content view? Should I consider rasterization solutions such as CATiledLayer?

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:35:40

*Thread Reply:* To start, it might be better to try and see if you can flatten it and use a single shape layer instead of several separate ones. You should be able to combine the shapes together by using things like CGPathCreateCopyByUnioningPath.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:36:33

*Thread Reply:* Depending on what you're trying to do, it might even be better to try and use a Metal shader instead.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:36:45

*Thread Reply:* I encourage you to schedule a lab appointment so we can look at it together!

üëç Chang
Chang
2022-06-07 21:37:25

*Thread Reply:* @James M (Apple) Actually having one giant shape layer with huge amount of points is performing worse. I had to split a long stroke into multiple CAShapeLayers to prevent frame drops.

Chang
2022-06-07 21:39:16

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôve never used Metal before, it seems daunting. Where should I start? I‚Äôm simply trying to add a lot of bezier paths into the canvas.

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:40:53

*Thread Reply:* You can try shouldRasterize = YES, which can be set on the shape layer or some super layer. Sometimes that will avoid the perf issues.

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:41:37

*Thread Reply:* You might want to try using SwiftUI Canvas, which you can embed in your UIKit app if you need to. SwiftUI Canvas uses Metal to render the draw commands you issue it, so it‚Äôs very performant.

üëç James M (Apple)
Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:41:40

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/Canvas

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:42:09

*Thread Reply:* Caveat: shouldRasterize does slow down animation though, so keep it on only when your UI is at rest.

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:42:16

*Thread Reply:* It won‚Äôt give you as much control as using Metal directly, but if you just need simple bezier paths, it might be a good higher level fit.

Chang
2022-06-07 21:42:42

*Thread Reply:* Actually it‚Äôs for inking, so I‚Äôll need to be able to dynamically add points, as well as moving them around.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:42:53

*Thread Reply:* You may also want to try making a custom UIView subclass, override drawRect() , and use CoreGraphics to draw the ink strokes instead. This will allow you to only draw the strokes that are visible (in the rect parameter passed in to drawRect).

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:43:42

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, so you would bracket your addition/animation/moving code with shouldRasterize = NO and shouldRasterize = YES.

Chang
2022-06-07 21:44:36

*Thread Reply:* Does scrolling in the scroll view count as animation?

Chang
2022-06-07 21:45:02

*Thread Reply:* Also, if I turn on shouldRasterize, things get blurry after I zoom in. How do I trigger a rerender?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:45:20

*Thread Reply:* It shouldn't, but YMMV. The idea is that if nothing changes within the shape layer, it should be safe to rasterize w/o negative impact.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:45:40

*Thread Reply:* I think you should be able to call setNeedsDisplay

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:45:48

*Thread Reply:* Scrolling does not count as animation. Animation would be if you were animating the individual CAShapeLayer between different bezier paths. Animating the position of CAShapeLayers with shouldRasterize enabled should also be okay.

Chang
2022-06-07 21:47:39

*Thread Reply:* So, I have a giant container UIView (inside a scrollview), containing a ton of small but overlapping CAShapeLayers. What‚Äôs the difference between turning on shouldRasterize on the container view vs. the individual shapelayers?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:49:59

*Thread Reply:* I would guess that rasterizing the container view would be most performant, because scrolling would only be moving the one rasterized bitmap, rather than having to recomposite multiple bitmaps. But you'll really have to try this out to see if it works for you.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:51:02

*Thread Reply:* Another thing you can try is setting drawsAsynchronously = true on the shape layers. This will allow the layers to perform the actual drawing on background threads, which may be faster, but since it won't be synchronized with the main loop, you might "see" the strokes being drawn independent of the current CA transaction.

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:52:55

*Thread Reply:* I think setting shouldRasterize on only the container view will rasterize all of the overlapping CAShapeLayers into one bitmap. Setting shouldRasterize on the only the individual CAShapeLayers will rasterize each bezier path separately, and CA will not cache the composition of them all together. I‚Äôm not sure which of these is more or less performant, and the answer might depend on your implementation.

Chang
2022-06-07 21:55:31

*Thread Reply:* Say I have a 10000pt height container view with two tiny shape layers on top-left and bottom-right, does setting shouldRasterize on the container view create a giant bitmap that will kill the app due to memory pressure?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:59:29

*Thread Reply:* When I worked practically on these sorts of issues, I would have to tweak shouldRasterize depending on what was being displayed. E.g. turn it off for large shapes, turn it on for small shapes. You may even have to figure out which shapes could be combined in a rasterization e.g. by putting them in a common layer and setting the flag there.

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:01:19

*Thread Reply:* The main advantage of CAShapeLayer here (vs some manual rasterization like drawing into a context) is good memory use for large, unrasterized shapes and inbuilt animation between states.

Chang
2022-06-07 22:02:20

*Thread Reply:* I noticed that with a lot of CAShapeLayer, backboardd gets saturated causing the frame drops, while none of my app‚Äôs CPU and GPU are high.

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:05:58

*Thread Reply:* CALayers (including CAShapeLayer) are rendered with Metal in another process (as you‚Äôve observed), so that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre seeing that process get saturated, not your own.

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:07:34

*Thread Reply:* > Say I have a 10000pt height container view with two tiny shape layers on top-left and bottom-right, does setting shouldRasterize on the container view create a giant bitmap that will kill the app due to memory pressure? I think the memory pressure would be in another process, not your app (since CAShapeLayer is rendered out of process), but in general I think this would cause memory pressure on the system. So I don‚Äôt think you want to use shouldRasterize on large layers.

Chang
2022-06-07 22:08:43

*Thread Reply:* Is there a way to debug memory use by this rendering process?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:20:20

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a good question, and I‚Äôm not sure. Can you put these questions together in a developer forum post? If you paste the link to a post here, I can forward it on to the Core Animation team.

Chang
2022-06-07 22:43:35

*Thread Reply:* Hmm, I‚Äôm afraid I don‚Äôt have time right now to write a post. Is there a lab I can go to to talk to the CA team? Is it Core Graphics Lab or UIKit lab?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:40:11

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm afraid not. A forum post is the best way to communicate with the Core Animation team.

James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:52:02

*Thread Reply:* Yes, we have labs on Thursday and Friday. Make sure to sign up!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:44:53

@Christopher asked > What's the simplest way to edit the AirDropped file's thumbnail and filename for the iOS sharesheet? > > Is there an updated or modern best practice version of the sample code: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/samplecode/sc2273/Introduction/Intro.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/DTS40013842

‚úÖ Christopher
Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:48:48

*Thread Reply:* Provide a LPLinkMetadata object to the activity view controller. The easiest way to do this is using a UIActivityItemsConfiguration object.

```let sharedItem = NSItemProvider(contentsOf: url)

let aic = UIActivityItemsConfiguration(itemProviders: [sharedItem])

let previewImage = UIImage(...) let previewImageProvider = NSItemProvider(object: previewImage)

let lm = LPLinkMetadata() lm.URL = url lm.imageProvider = previewImageProvider

aic.linkMetadata = lm

let avc = UIActivityViewController(activityItemsConfiguration: aic)

// present avc```

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:00:39

@Alessandro asked > Hi, how can I change some properties of NSWindow (such as the titlebar color) when using Catalyst?

John T (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:01:43

*Thread Reply:* Use the UITitlebarTitleVisibilityHidden option on UITitlebar.titleVisibility to disable the titlebar material, window title, and its toolbar. You can then provide your own view underneath. The window‚Äôs safe area insets still apply and the area beyond those insets remain draggable. Note that the UITitlebar cannot have an NSToolbar in order for this to work.

John T (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:02:29

*Thread Reply:* Also feel free to file feedback requesting enhancements if you wish to do this while maintaining a window toolbar!

Alessandro
2022-06-07 22:04:55

*Thread Reply:* Therefore there is no way I can keep the window toolbar so that the user can still see (for example) the window title (and modify the background color at the same time)?

Owen M (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:09:37

*Thread Reply:* That is correct, there is no way to do that by default. But if you set the titlebar visibility hidden, since you then manage your own content in that region you can add a UILabel with the window title

Jeff N (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:11:33

*Thread Reply:* Design-wise, on macOS we do generally prefer to use the standard toolbar/titlebar backing for consistency across the system. It plays an important role in communicating which window is currently frontmost. There are exceptions, like the new Weather app, but they‚Äôre fairly exceptional.

Jeff N (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:12:56

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs totally OK to go for something custom (we love creative designs!) but if you do, you‚Äôre also taking responsibility for those affordances.

Alessandro
2022-06-07 22:25:38

*Thread Reply:* @Jeff N (Apple) Thanks for the suggestion! In fact, I was trying to keep the titlebar in order to give the Catalyst app a more ‚ÄúmacOS‚Äù feel, but without simulating the default appearance with custom labels, since it almost never looks quite the same as the system

Bruce N (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:18:19

Tyler - I think you meant to use the Ask a Question Workflow. We can‚Äôt respond to an idea.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:22:13

@Nikhil asked > I saw an app that shows the multitasking dots at the top of the screen, but still hides the reset of the status area. I could not figure out how to do that. Do you have a suggestion on how best to do this?

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:22:47

*Thread Reply:* I think returning true from an override of prefersStatusBarHidden on a view controller in your app will achieve this effect.

Nikhil
2022-06-07 22:28:48

*Thread Reply:* Ah, yes, that does it. Thank you!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:22:53

@Tyler asked > UIHostingConfiguration question - I was expecting onAppear calls to be made on the hosted Views as cells move on screen, but it seems that they line up with (I assume?) the reused cell population. If I adjust your UseSwiftUIWithUIKit demo to increase the cell counts and add a print on onAppear I see fewer logs than I would expect to see. And no logging once I scroll through all of the content. Curious if this expected behavior before, or a function of this being beta?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:23:30

*Thread Reply:* Great question, the intent is for onAppear used inside UIHostingConfiguration to behave like it does in a SwiftUI List, however it‚Äôs a known issue in the current iOS 16 beta that it isn‚Äôt called with the expected timing üëç

Tyler
2022-06-07 22:24:02

*Thread Reply:* Fantastic, thank you!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:42:26

@Nikhil asked > I would like to allow users to configure command keys for menus in my app. However, I have not found a way to change the command keys (or add / remove menus) after the initial builder phase occurs (via the AppDelegate). As a test, I built my menus, and then used a Dispatch after to remove the View menu after 4 seconds. I'm reusing the same builder that was passed in. However, nothing happens. Is the expected? Is there a way to update the command keys after launch?

Anant J (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:43:57

*Thread Reply:* Updating the main menu needs to happen synchronously in the -buildMenuWithBuilder: method. If you want to update the main menu later, you need to call UIMenuSystem.main.setNeedsRebuild(), and that‚Äôll call buildMenuWithBuilder again (lazily).

üëç Nikhil
Nikhil
2022-06-07 22:45:07

*Thread Reply:* awesome!

Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:05:37

*Thread Reply:* Also note that on macOS / Catalyst, it is best to avoid a dynamically changing menu bar structure. All items should be in the same location at all times, so they're easy to discover and their location is easy to remember. Instead of adding/removing items, use validation to disable items when they are not applicable.

üëç Nikhil
Bruce N (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:01:34

Thank you for joining us for this Q&A! I hope you had as much fun as we did üòé. There is another UIFrameworks Q&A scheduled for tomorrow. And two 2 hour labs where you can interact directly with a UIFrameworks engineers on Thursday and Friday. We hope to see you in these other events!

üôå Dima G (Apple), Cristian-Mihai, Leonard, Jamie M (Apple)
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:04:30

@Nikhil asked > Catalyst question: I would like create a custom cursor that is dependent on settings in the UI that only works inside a specific view (e.g., a tool). Normally on Mac, that would be done with an NSTrackingArea. Since UIPointerInteraction is not supported on Mac, how should I go about doing this?

Owen M (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:06:47

*Thread Reply:* UIPointerInteraction should work with Mac Catalyst, and allow you to customize the cursor using NSCursor API when hovering inside a view using its UIPointerInteractionDelegate methods. Can you share some more detail about where you are seeing this not work? If this isn‚Äôt working, please file a feedback with a sample project so we can take a closer look!

Nikhil
2022-06-07 23:16:51

*Thread Reply:* OK - I'm a little confused by what you wrote. I have code which uses UIPointerInteraction and implements the delegate's func pointerInteraction(_ interaction: UIPointerInteraction,styleFor region: UIPointerRegion) On iOS, I get the desired cursor: let cursor = UIBezierPath(ovalIn: rect) return UIPointerStyle(shape: UIPointerShape.path(cursor)) That does not do anything on Mac. It sounds like I should conditionalize inside the delegate method and call NSCursor?

Nikhil
2022-06-07 23:21:09

*Thread Reply:* Ah, I should use willEnter /willExit and call NSCursor.

‚úÖ Owen M (Apple)
Owen M (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:21:36

*Thread Reply:* Ah, yes. UIPointerStyle is available on Mac Catalyst to reduce conditionalization, but won‚Äôt affect the NSCursor appearance the same way it does on iPad. And yep, that was just the answer I was typing out!

Nikhil
2022-06-07 23:25:26

*Thread Reply:* Thank you - the thing I noticed is that if the cursor is already in the view, then the cursor doesn't get set (e.g., if you have the mouse over something and you click, which then displays a new view which now encompasses the cursor. In that case, the methods for willEnter gets called but the cursor doesn't update for some reason. I have to move the cursor out of the view and back in (I have logging to show that).

Nikhil
2022-06-07 23:25:49

*Thread Reply:* If that's not expected, I can make a project + feedback.

2022-06-07 23:38:11

Florian
2022-06-07 23:11:24

Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H9K1JYJY/p1654627443299689
Thread in <b>#uiframeworks-lounge</b>
üëç Eric, Philip
Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:14:21

*Thread Reply:* > Is it now possible to create custom app-specific extensions that are not pre-defined by Apple or am I misreading the ExtensionKit docs? It is possible for macOS apps to define an extension point. Other 3rd party apps can then embed AppExtensions that target the extension point. > If this is possible, is there a good session to watch this week? There are no sessions planned for ExtensionKit this week. (edited)

:the_horns: Eric
Eric
2022-06-07 23:17:53

*Thread Reply:* Great news! This is something I'm excited for even if it only works with macOS.

Eric
2022-06-07 23:19:26

*Thread Reply:* Are these extensions App Store compatible?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:21:45

*Thread Reply:* Yes.

üëè Eric
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:22:22

@Artur asked > Probably it is more core services but I can't find anything like that, so: > We have a case where iPad is the heart of a system. Or rather iPads. In the aircraft cockpit it is one of the most powerful and flexible units. Now - we need two or more devices to communicate (pilot, co-pilot, cabin crew...). Yet regulators have very specific need that one device is a master and manages synchronization with others. > > We found that iPad is not providing things like services (e.g. http/soap/rest/socket server) that would be running no matter if app is open or closed (pilots are using many apps for different purposes) - is that achievable in any way? > > Clients would love to see iPad-only solution but we are limited now to use windows machine acting as server and iPad devices are just clients (with quite similar functionality).

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:22:51

*Thread Reply:* This is a very great question. Right now it is not generally possible to have code running indefinitely while an app is in the background. We have special endpoints for things like voip but do not support generic background processes. I‚Äôd suggest filing feedback and also reaching out to evangelism about potential use cases that you might have for this.

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:32:16

*Thread Reply:* Also a disclaimer: this question has legal implications since you are mentioning aviation which is explicitly mentioned in the iPadOS license agreement under 7.5. So the answer above is purely based on the technical feasibility as we can not give you legal advice here.

Sherwin
2022-06-07 23:47:41

*Thread Reply:* @Artur Wondering if Multipeer Connectivity framework would work for you.

John
2022-06-07 23:49:31

*Thread Reply:* Multipeer is odd cause there's no real ‚Äúhost‚Äù and ‚Äúclient‚Äù‚Ä¶. You could manage a host using communicated meta data though.

I also think you disconnect from the network when the app gets backgrounded too‚Ä¶

Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:59

*Thread Reply:* You might want to take a look at CoreBluetooth, as it explicitly allows an app to continue scanning for peripherals while backgrounded. See this doc

This is not a recommendation for your application. Please contact developer relations to explore legal and other implications.

developer.apple.com
Core Bluetooth Background Processing for iOS Apps
Explains how to develop Mac and iOS apps that interact with Bluetooth low energy technology.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/NetworkingInternetWeb/Conceptual/CoreBluetooth_concepts/CoreBluetoothBackgroundProcessingForIOSApps/PerformingTasksWhileYourAppIsInTheBackground.html
Gino D (Apple)

Navigation Styles üßµ

üß≠ Anant J (Apple), Dima G (Apple), Louis B (Apple), Bino G (Apple)
David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:11:01

*Thread Reply:* This morning we had a question about directly implementing a browser-style UI. Of note UIKit doesn‚Äôt provide backward & forward. We would recommend the chevron.backward and chevron.forward images for generating buttons for this (in the leading position). Happy to discuss this further as well!

Anil Abraham
2022-06-08 01:24:31

*Thread Reply:* That was me! I started working on this and have a further question: how would you go about making sure the forward button enabled state is always in sync? Since the buttons are set on the UINavigationItem, there's one for each VC in the stack and keeping track of them all and setting isEnabled on each every time the nav stack changes is cumbersome.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:37:30

*Thread Reply:* Thats a good question. I think the simplest might be to have each VC register with your stack object to track its enablement. Its boilerplate code for sure but there are all manner of technologies that we have to help you build that kind of abstraction

Anil Abraham
2022-06-08 01:57:11

*Thread Reply:* Ah, that's too bad. I was hoping canPerformAction or something would be called for the bar button item, but it seems not

Gino D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:08:56

üéØ Russell L (Apple), Bino G (Apple), Louis B (Apple), Dima G (Apple), Anna K (Apple), Sean
Duncan
2022-06-08 01:11:52

*Thread Reply:* No question. I‚Äôm just excited at how easy this is, and to implement this in my upcoming redesign of an iOS app to have iPad and macOS versions. üéÅ üôè:skintone3:

üòπ David D (Apple)
üôå Dima G (Apple), David J (Apple), Bruce N (Apple)

‚ù§Ô∏è Russell L (Apple), Andy L (Apple), Aditya K (Apple)

Gino D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:13:55

Title Menu üßµ

Now that we‚Äôve gotten a taste for Desktop Class iPad, we‚Äôd love to hear your questions! Hit the lightning bolt icon ‚ö° in the lower left and select ‚ÄúAsk a question‚Äù to shoot us your question so our team can work on getting you an answer! We‚Äôll repost the question and try to get as many of them answered as possible! ‚≠êüèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è:skintone3:üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è:skintone3:üèÉ:skintone3:

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:22:58

@Steve asked > Looks great! I assume apps that already have a More (overflow) menu should migrate the items to additionalOverflowItems. Is that correct?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:23:33

*Thread Reply:* for iOS 16 I would say definitely! In part it will help you a lot in Stage Manager, as you won‚Äôt have to do as much to respond to size changes

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:24:24

*Thread Reply:* there are a few different ways to interact with it. centerItemGroups will flow into it first, but so will trailing items (as a group via the older rightBarButtonItems API, and by-group in the new trailingItemGroups API).

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:25:05

*Thread Reply:* there is also the additionalOverflowItems that can be used to add content directly to the overflow button‚Äôs menu ‚Äì we think this will be rare, but can be useful for specific use cases.

Steve
2022-06-08 01:30:45

*Thread Reply:* Thank you. And from the sample code, it looks like the optional group does NOT flow into the overflow button's menu.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:31:17

*Thread Reply:* optional groups should flow if there isn‚Äôt enough room

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:31:51

*Thread Reply:* but items that are not in the customization currently go no where (not directly accessible). We‚Äôre considering some control over that behavior however.

Steve
2022-06-08 01:34:33

*Thread Reply:* That was what I was getting at. For apps with lots of commands, that would be helpful. Would you like a radar üôÇ

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:34:43

*Thread Reply:* always helpful!

Steve
2022-06-08 01:37:44

*Thread Reply:* Will do. Excellent presentation, David. Thank you.

:gratitude_thank_you: David D (Apple)
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:30:00

@Duncan asked > This may not be a question with a straightforward answer, but... A degree of consensus in the developer community prior to the current beta releases has been that using SwiftUI inside Catalyst is the most difficult path, and it would be better to target macOS natively directly with SwiftUI. In trying to give the best desktop-class experience on iPad, would it be your recommendation to using a native SwiftUI app, if that is an option, or a Catalyst app with SwiftUI components?

Duncan
2022-06-08 01:30:32

*Thread Reply:* Poorly worded as of course what I mean is desktop-class experience on iPad while also targeting macOS as well...

Bruce N (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:32:23

*Thread Reply:* Catalyst support is continuously improving. I think that it really depends on on which works best for your App. If you have the luxury to try both you might want to compare the outcomes of each.

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:36:05

*Thread Reply:* Basically use whatever works best for your concrete situation. There is no one size fits all solution. The range here can be from an app 100% written in UIKit to 100% written in SwiftUI. And it could be a macOS version written in AppKit, using Catalyst or SwiftUI.

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:42:57

*Thread Reply:* In what state is your current code base?

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:43:09

*Thread Reply:* Is this an iPad app you're transitioning to the Mac?

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:43:32

*Thread Reply:* > Poorly worded as of course what I mean is desktop-class experience on iPad while also targeting macOS as well... Oops, just saw this

Scott
2022-06-08 01:45:09

*Thread Reply:* What stood out for me in the What's New in SwiftUI session was the advances in Forms. Previously, Forms on macOS seemed to require some, platform specific additions to get nice looking layouts without using Catalyst. With iOS 16 and macOS 13, it looks like you can get great looking Form layouts with nearly the same SwiftUI views. Really nice!

Duncan
2022-06-10 06:43:48

*Thread Reply:* Late to the party to see these additional replies. üôÇ My app code base is currently all UIKit, pretty tidy, ready to be modular and move to the next ideal UI architecture.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:40:24

@Jason asked > Are there any particular reasons (that you can reveal) for why there‚Äôs no general UIHostingView, only UIHostingController, whereas AppKit has NSHostingView available?

üëç Chang
James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:41:30

*Thread Reply:* This is intentional, because our architecture relies on a UIView being a part of a view controller hierarchy (and thus, being "owned" by a view controller). Think of things like modal presentations, responder chain, etc.

Sara F (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:42:51

*Thread Reply:* This is partially touched on in Use SwiftUI with UIKit as well! https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072

Apple Developer
Use SwiftUI with UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how to take advantage of the power of SwiftUI in your UIKit app. Build custom UICollectionView and UITableView cells seamlessly...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10072
üëç James M (Apple), Matthew
Jason
2022-06-08 01:48:50

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:49:46

@Haolun asked > Will SwiftUI slowly replace UIKit? I'm surprised that there is still a lot of content focused on UIKit this year. This video is mostly about UIKit code and I was wondering how I can implement them in SwiftUI, like the editor style toolbar?

James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:50:11

*Thread Reply:* SwiftUI and UIKit are two different layers of abstraction, and one is not supplanting the other. When deciding what to use for your app, you should pick whatever is the best tool for the job.

üôå Honghao
üëç Honghao
James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:51:26

*Thread Reply:* Taylor K also had a great answer to this: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654645179571169?thread_ts=1654645084.628639&cid=C03HX19UNCQ

üëè Bruce N (Apple), Steve M (Apple), Michael O (Apple), Jamie M (Apple)
Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:51:44

*Thread Reply:* To add to this, for a lot of developers this means a mix of UIKit and SwiftUI, but it can also mean to start a new app that is written 100% in SwiftUI or UIKit.

Taylor K (Apple)
2022-06-08 02:02:07

@Roman asked > Is there any reason why Live Text feature is not supported in iOS Keyboard extensions? > Using the API either crashes the extension or just prints error logs, depending on the iOS version.

Kasia W (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:54:08

James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:56:22

*Thread Reply:* Keep in mind also that the operating system maintains a much stricter memory allowance for keyboard extensions, so it's pretty likely that your extension is being killed by the OS for using too much memory.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:54:06

@Vince asked > For UIEditMenuInteraction, all the examples in the sessions showed APPPENDING items to the menu. Is it possible to have our custom items at the beginning or even mixed in with the 'suggested' ones if we appropriately shuffle them into the returned menu?

James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:54:49

*Thread Reply:* You can! suggestedActions is just an array, so you can prepend to it, append to it, or just return a UIMenu with an entirely different set of children if you want.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:12:20

*Thread Reply:* it should just work, so that sounds like a bug, thanks for filing!

üëç Paolo
Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:12:45

*Thread Reply:* This should work on iPhone. The menu filters out actions that are not supported and we start searching the responder chain from the content view controller. Are you implementing canPerformAction: or similar methods by any chance?

Paolo
2022-06-08 19:15:14

*Thread Reply:* No I'm not using canPerformAction: here. I am presenting a sheet (without dimming) but if I dismiss it the issue is still there

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:16:06

*Thread Reply:* If you can attach a sample project to the feedback that would be extremely helpful. But yeah if you are running the exact same code on iOS than on iPadOS, that should work.

Paolo
2022-06-08 19:27:06

üõ†Ô∏è Title menu actions üßµ

üôå Louis B (Apple), Dima G (Apple)
Maciej
2022-06-08 19:12:20

*Thread Reply:* Are there any requirements for UINavigationItem.documentProperties and UINavigationItem.titleMenuProvider to correctly setup title item and it‚Äôs menu? I can‚Äôt find a way for it to work for my custom document file type (which works OK with other system integration points). All I get is empty (completely transparent) title item which shows menu with just a header menu element, without any other actions like duplicate/rename etc. Should it work in current seed, or I‚Äôm hitting a bug?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:14:07

*Thread Reply:* yea, this sounds like a bug to me. See also the ‚ÄúTitle menu header‚Äù thread.

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:14:27

*Thread Reply:* The title menu will filter out all actions you don‚Äôt support. Are you implementing the new action methods like duplicate:, export: etc.?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:14:29

*Thread Reply:* the document properties pulls a preview in much the same way you would get it in Files, so I would expect the same preview

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:15:21

*Thread Reply:* would be interesting to get some more info on how you set up the document properties. Also note that the title in the navigation bar is not affected by that, so you still have to configure that yourself.

Maciej
2022-06-08 19:20:37

*Thread Reply:* So title item should display UINavigationItem.title , right?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:21:55

*Thread Reply:* yea

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:21:57

*Thread Reply:* yes

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:24:18

*Thread Reply:* The titleMenuProvider or documentProperties being set only adds the chevron to present the menu. The document properties are then defining the appearance of the header in that menu and the menu provider the other items, assuming the content view controller actually implements the action methods relevant for that. Rename is a bit special in that you don‚Äôt have to implement rename: (but you can if you want to roll your own) because UINavigationController implements it for you if you set a renameDelegate.

üôå Maciej
Maciej
2022-06-08 19:31:33

*Thread Reply:* Guys, thank you very much! I got it all working now. The problem with empty title item was me,setting UINavigationItem.title to empty string from completely another place than I‚Äôm now trying new APIs. Adding export: and others helped as well.

But still ‚Äì when UINavigationItem.title is set to empty string, system does not show chevron, but tapping on this empty space displays menu.

One more time, many thanks! üôè üôå

2022-06-08 19:32:50

*Thread Reply:* yea, thats probably just a bug‚Ä¶ I have some bits to work on in that space <emoji not found>

‚ÜîÔ∏è Center items thread üßµ

üôå Louis B (Apple), Dima G (Apple)
Ian H (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:14:54

ü™Ñ Center item customization thread üßµ

üôå Louis B (Apple), Dima G (Apple)
Ian H (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:17:34

üåä Overflow menu üßµ

üôå Louis B (Apple)
David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:19:25

*Thread Reply:* Of note both UIBarButtonItem and UIBarButtonItemGroup have a menuRepresentation property. The item‚Äôs property will be used for both the representativeItem‚Äôs synthesized menu and in the overflow, but the group‚Äôs property is only used in overflow (if you want to customize the representativeItem ‚Äôs menu, just set one)

Vince
2022-06-08 19:19:32

*Thread Reply:* Maybe I missed it, but can you ‚Äòpre-fill‚Äô the overflow menu (i.e. not just items that fell off the bar due to real-estate?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:20:01

*Thread Reply:* You can add items to the overflow with UINavigationItem.additionalOverflowItems

üëç Vince
Vince
2022-06-08 19:20:22

*Thread Reply:* For the items in the overflow menu (or really any UIMenu), it is possible to provide a fully-custom MenuElement? I mean something where we provide a full UIView (or similar) vs. just what is supported by UIAction, etc.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:21:00

*Thread Reply:* We don‚Äôt have support for custom view menu elements

Vince
2022-06-08 19:21:30

*Thread Reply:* (off to Feedback Assistant‚Ä¶ üôÇ )

üëç Mohammed J (Apple), David D (Apple)
Vince
2022-06-08 19:22:05

*Thread Reply:* Is UIAction basically the only way to construct a UIMennuELement?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:22:41

*Thread Reply:* UIAction and UICommand are the common leaf-node UIMenuElements

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:22:52

*Thread Reply:* but they are both based on providing title/image/etc rather than a UIView

Vince
2022-06-08 19:23:07

*Thread Reply:* right

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:23:47

*Thread Reply:* aside from the custom view support, is there something specific your looking for?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:23:49

*Thread Reply:* UIAction are block-based, UICommand is selector-based. The former is best for very specific actions, the latter for general actions that could apply to many different responders.

üëç Tyler F (Apple)
Vince
2022-06-08 19:35:15

*Thread Reply:* Imagine a font size item, which in the toolbar, brings up a popover with a slider. Ideally, I‚Äôd want that slider to be directly in the overflow menu.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:38:20

*Thread Reply:* yea, we‚Äôve definitely thought of that, but there are some challenges to being able to make something that you can use (aside from just giving you exactly that). But as @Mohammed J (Apple) went through in the talk, we have added some other features to UIMenuElement to help make compact UIs that can do things like that, although not directly

Ian H (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:19:46

2022-06-08 19:23:13

üìù Edit menu integration üßµ

Vince
2022-06-08 19:23:38

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible for an app to request the vertical variant on phone or when using finger in text selection?

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:24:44

*Thread Reply:* It is not possible to present the full size context menus. We show the context menu when using trackpads on iPad with right-clicks.

Lukas
2022-06-08 19:25:17

*Thread Reply:* So vertical menus are still limited to system-driven invocation, even on iPad? Can't present them programmatically?

Andy L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:26:10

*Thread Reply:* That is correct

James M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:29:08

*Thread Reply:* It sounds like you might be looking for UIContextMenuInteraction instead? If you are presenting edit menu actions (like Cut, Copy, etc), you should use UIEditMenuInteraction without trying to force it to look different than the rest of the system.

Ian H (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:23:34
