UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:28:45

@Lukas asked > When an iPad is connected to a low dpi external monitor, will apps run at a 1x scale factor with 1x assets used? Or will they stay at 2x with some sort of downscaling?

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:29:17

*Thread Reply:* 1x external displays will always be reflected as 2x today.

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:29:30

*Thread Reply:* So you do not need to worry about providing 1x assets

Lukas
2022-06-08 19:31:34

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:32:11

*Thread Reply:* Np!

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:37:37

@Vince asked > For UIMenuElements, if I change the UIMenuElementAttributesHidden attribute while it's visible, will it disappear?

Vince
2022-06-08 19:40:01

*Thread Reply:* Similarly, if I change the title/image, do they update if already visible?

Mohammed J (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:42:19

*Thread Reply:* No, it won't. The only way to update a visible menu is using UIContextMenuInteraction.updateVisibleMenu() if you're using UIContextMenuInteraction directly, or by setting the button's menu property to a new value if you're using a UIButton. Menus are copied when consumed by the system, so any instance you may be holding onto is no longer directly connected to what's visible.

Vince
2022-06-08 19:42:45

*Thread Reply:* (off to Feedback Assistant)

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:39:34

@Matt asked > Not sure if this is the right time for this, but... > In iOS 16 UIDevice.name has changed to only return the model name (E.g "iPhone" instead of "Matt's internet communicator"). I think in one of the sessions I heard that there is an entitlement to get the old behaviour, but I can't find any reference to it anywhere.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:41:31

*Thread Reply:* The entitlement is com.apple.developer.device-information.user-assigned-device-name. You can find out more about it in the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs new in privacy‚Äù video.

üëç Matt
Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:43:01

*Thread Reply:* There are some restrictions around what you can do with it (more in that video).

Matt
2022-06-08 19:46:57

*Thread Reply:* In my case it would be on supervised devices, so hopefully not too restrictive

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:51:22

@Maciej asked > Navigation item center groups: does it make sense to swap them completely based on some factor, like object selection state? If so, should one change UINavigationItem.customizationIdentifier then? Any other considerations?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:52:36

*Thread Reply:* It can, and thats a valid use for multiple customization identifiers on a single UINavigationItem. We should continue to properly save & restore state when you update. I‚Äôm pretty sure we‚Äôll update things properly regardless of the relative ordering of you setting .centerItemGroups vs .customizationIdentifier, but if you find that not to be the case file a report

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:54:00

*Thread Reply:* if you just want to conditionally make functionality available though, you might look at using the hidden property we just added to UIBarButtonItem and UIBarButtonItemGroup

Maciej
2022-06-08 19:58:31

*Thread Reply:* Ohh, I missed hidden , seems useful. But I think for completely different modes, using different customization identifiers might make more sense. I will try to implement it and maybe on tomorrows labs (assuming I will get my ticket üòâ) I will share my experience.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:08:13

I think there are ways you might be able to get something useful like that, but I‚Äôd want to talk to the engineer that worked on edit menu interaction

@Raimundas asked > Do you think it's a good idea trying to convert modals to use structured concurrency on iOS? So instead of usual callback the caller would await on result property.

Russell L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:55:46

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:01:36

@Maciej asked > Do UIMenuElementAttributesKeepsMenuPresented and UIMenuElementSize translate to same/similar behaviour in Mac Catalyst?

Mohammed J (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:04:41

*Thread Reply:* Since macOS menus are modal, UIMenuElementAttributesKeepsMenuPresented has no effect on the Mac. Small or medium UIMenuElementSizes will produce standard (full width) menu elements since that design paradigm doesn't exist on the Mac.

üëå Maciej
Maciej
2022-06-08 20:09:25

*Thread Reply:* I thought so, but was worth asking üôÇ Not having UIMenuElementAttributesKeepsMenuPresented -like behaviour seems particularly problematic, since it enables great UX on iPad. With no direct Mac behaviour, one must look for completely different solution there.

Mohammed J (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:10:20

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, that's totally understandable. It's just incompatible with how Mac menus work currently.

2022-06-08 22:30:38

@Duncan asked > I am wondering how many of these API are available in a native SwiftUI app? > > I am taking my iOS app to both iPadOS and macOS in a current redesign, which will require iOS 16/can require macOS 13, but I need to decide between using Catalyst vs. going SwiftUI native.

Raleigh L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:31:13

*Thread Reply:* If your writing a pure SwiftUI app, then you should compile it native for each platform.

Duncan
2022-06-08 22:31:13

*Thread Reply:* e.g. disabling the traffic light buttons when not applicable.

Raleigh L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:03

*Thread Reply:* does your SwiftUI app rely on UIKit for something?

Duncan
2022-06-08 22:34:33

*Thread Reply:* The question is the opposite, really. It‚Äôs currently a UIKit app. I am at the point of needing to decide‚Äîdo I ship it for macOS with Catalyst, or given I‚Äôm doing a major redesign anyway, do I migrate it to be a SwiftUI app.

I am wondering‚Äîare any of the features/capabilities shown here in deploying as a Catalyst app that are not available on macOS using a native SwiftUI app?

Raleigh L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:36:37

Duncan
2022-06-08 22:36:43

*Thread Reply:* OK

Owen M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:37:11

*Thread Reply:* If you already have a UIKit app that‚Äôs working well, proceeding with a Catalyst app would definitely be the quickest path to Mac, and you can always start to mix and match SwiftUI alongside at the same time if you aren‚Äôt ready to commit fully. As far as how these properties are exposed in SwiftUI, I‚Äôm not sure off the top of my head, but there are additional SwiftUI Q&As that should be able to provide a concrete answer for you

üëç:skin_tone_3: Duncan
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:31:50

@George asked > We have a CallKit VOIP app that supports iPad (along with iPhone) and we want to use it as a Mac app for Apple silicon Macs. We have two issues: > > 1) On Mac there is no request for microphone access. The microphone request as it is on iOS/iPadOS is not compatible on macOS? We should add different permission requests according the available platform (iOS vs macOS)? > > 2) On Mac there is no CallKit UI for the incoming calls? The expectation here is to just run our app and make the app's windows the front window without any CallKit UI view or status bar indicator? > > Thank you!!

Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:37:27

*Thread Reply:* PushKit will deliver the VoIP push, and it's delivered to the app, which is launched if needed. But on macOS, CallKit will not provide any UI. It is up to your app to provide its own UI when it receives the payload.

I'm not certain about the microphone access question. That might be something best asked in one of the upcoming labs for AVAudioSession, AVKit, or AVFoundation.

Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:47:57

*Thread Reply:* Which API are you using to attempt microphone access?

Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:53:45

*Thread Reply:* @George?

George
2022-06-08 22:53:55

*Thread Reply:* Oh, I see! So, the launch of the app is what expected on VoIP push reception without UI. Then, we are OK with that!

We should only see the microphone access issue‚Ä¶

Hmm, I don't have access in our code right now (out of office time zone here). But, as far as remember we use AVAudioSession and we check if category == PLAYANDRECORD in order to check microphone availability‚Ä¶

Jason B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:56:39

*Thread Reply:* There are two upcoming AVAudioSession labs: June 9th from 11-2 PDT and June 10th from 1-3 PDT. That would be the best place to get your microphone access question answered.

George
2022-06-08 23:00:09

*Thread Reply:* Thank you guys, @Jason B (Apple) and @Nils B (Apple) I'll check the labs and I'll be prepared with the exact microphone request code that we use! üëã

üôå Nils B (Apple), Jason B (Apple)
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:33:37

@Ortwin asked > I'm trying to hide my UINavigationBar bar with .slide. However, the hiding animation is broken, it disappears in one go. The show animation slides in correctly though. Is this a known issue?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:34:04

*Thread Reply:* I would suspect that your doing something that UIKit isn‚Äôt really prepared to manage properly ‚Äì can you paste in the code your using?

David D (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:56:41

*Thread Reply:* even without an example, my rough guess here would be that if your setting UINavigationController.isNavigationBarHidden we are probably just pulling the navigation bar out of the hierarchy before your animation begins. If you are calling it with animated:true then we may just be doing things that preclude your animation entirely. And if your setting UINavigationBar.isHidden then that won‚Äôt be animatable

Ortwin
2022-06-09 17:03:06

*Thread Reply:* I'm hiding the status bar simultaneously to get a full screen experience. When I remove the status bar animation, the nav bar animates fine. FB8980917 has a sample app.

David D (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:25:55

*Thread Reply:* I pulled up the sample from that issue, it seems to be working in iOS 16, have you tried it there? (I haven‚Äôt checked on anything older at the moment, so not sure if this is a new change or not)

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:11:00

@Matthew asked > macOS ExtensionKit question. Does an extension have to be delivered within an app bundle? Is it possible to build a standalone .appex and have it be discoverable by an hosting application?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:14:13

*Thread Reply:* It is not possible to deliver an extension outside of an app bundle. Extensions must be contained in an app bundle in the Extensions directory.

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:16:36

*Thread Reply:* Ah hello! Thanks for your help yesterday!

Would be awesome to not need to create wrapper apps to deliver extension-only payloads. I‚Äôll file a bug report.

Will all of ExtensionKit‚Äôs capabilities be available to apps delivered outside the App Store using Developer ID?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:21:46

*Thread Reply:* Happy to help.

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:25:09

*Thread Reply:* Yes ExtensionKit‚Äôs capabilities are supported apps delivered outside of the App Store. The host app and the extension must be code signed and the extension must be sandboxed.

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:29:55

*Thread Reply:* Ah this is great info - particularly about the sandboxing requirements for extensions!

I‚Äôm just getting started, so perhaps this is a silly question. But, I‚Äôve been playing with the extension Xcode template, and it is helpful it getting an idea of how to structure everything. I find myself doing awkward things to get at the NSXPCConnection and its properties, since it is only available from the AppExtensionConfiguration. I‚Äôm just passing it right though back up to the main extension class. Does this sound like it makes sense?

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:31:27

*Thread Reply:* Is there any way for my main app to pass security-scoped bookmarks, or other privileged file-access mechanism back down to the extension, or will each extension that needs this kind of thing need to request access from the user itself?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:42:08

*Thread Reply:* ExtensionKit doesn't provide specific API to grant file access to an extension. I'm not knowledgeable enough about security scoped bookmarks to comment at the moment.

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:43:23

*Thread Reply:* Ok that‚Äôs totally understandable. But, could an extension create an open dialog for gaining file access?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:46:54

*Thread Reply:* Yes, extensions can use NSOpenPannel

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:48:23

*Thread Reply:* Ok wonderful! And from my frantic internet searching just now, it does seem possible to share file accesses between apps and XPC services. So, I feel like that covers what I would need.

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:50:58

*Thread Reply:* I realize that I‚Äôm perhaps monopolizing your time/attention. Please feel free to ignore as needed üòÉ

Do you have any thoughts on the best way to communicate the NSXPCConnection from the configuration back up to the extension class? I‚Äôm envisioning needing to use the remoteObject and exportedObject from extensions for bidirectional communication with the host app.

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:56:20

*Thread Reply:* WRT configuring XPC connections:

We recommend that the app that defines the extension point provided a framework to extension developers. This framework should specialize the ExtensionKit protocols. This is a quick example of something such a framework might implement

```struct ExampleConfiguration<E:ExampleExtension>: AppExtensionConfiguration {

let exportedObject: ExportedObject

init(_ appExtension: E) {
    self.exportedObject = ExportedObject(appExtension)
}

/// Determine whether to accept the XPC connection from the host.
func accept(connection: NSXPCConnection) -&gt; Bool {

    connection.exportedInterface = NSXPCInterface(with: TextTransformerXPCProtocol.self)
    connection.exportedObject = exportedObject
    connection.resume()

    return true
}

class ExportedObject: NSObject, TextTransformerXPCProtocol {
    let appExtension: E

    init(_ appExtension: E) {
        self.appExtension = appExtension
    }

    func transform(text: String, reply: (String) -&gt; Void) {
        let transformedText = appExtension.transform(text: text)
        reply(transformedText)
    }
}

}

/// The AppExtension protocol to which this extension will conform. /// This is typically defined by the extension host in a framework. protocol ExampleExtension : AppExtension { func transform(text: String) -> String }

extension ExampleExtension { var configuration: ExampleConfiguration<some ExampleExtension> { // Return your extension's configuration upon request. return ExampleConfiguration(self) } } ```

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:57:54

*Thread Reply:* An extension implementation would look like this:

```@main final class ExampleAppExtension: ExampleExtension {

func transform(text: String) -&gt; String {
    return text.uppercased()
}

}```

Matthew
2022-06-09 00:59:01

*Thread Reply:* ok this makes total sense, and is really helpful. Thank you very much!

Matthew
2022-06-09 01:02:01

*Thread Reply:* Is there any way that I could accept-list locally-bundled extensions within the host app? Or, would those always need explicit user approval as well?

Matthew
2022-06-09 01:03:09

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:09:05

*Thread Reply:* Correct

Matthew
2022-06-09 01:10:02

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:11:49

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you can file feedback if this will cause problems.

Matthew
2022-06-09 01:16:28

*Thread Reply:* My cursory testing with extensions seems to have a lower first-request latency than a plain XPC service, which would be really cool! Am I right about that?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:24:46

*Thread Reply:* Extensions are launched when the host creates the AppExtensionProcess instance so it is already running by the time you send the first XPC message. If you include the time waiting for the AppExtensionProcess instance to be created I suspect the overall latency will be equivalent. I have not measured this.

Matthew
2022-06-09 01:27:12

*Thread Reply:* Ok this makes sense.

I was also curious about the .appextensionpoint file. Aside from documentation, which I assume is forthcoming, it was interesting this wasn‚Äôt incorporated into the app‚Äôs Info.plist. Is there something here than made separate files a better fit?

Alex C (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:43:06

*Thread Reply:* I have an answer for this: > Is there any way for my main app to pass security-scoped bookmarks, or other privileged file-access mechanism back down to the extension, or will each extension that needs this kind of thing need to request access from the user itself? You can expect Security scoped bookmarks to grant the extension access to files that the host app has access to.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:15:46

*Thread Reply:* You can use UIFontDescriptor.TraitKey.widthwith a float value.

We know that some suggested constants for the various ‚Äòstandard‚Äô widths would be helpful - like the constants for ‚Äòstandard‚Äô widths for the use with UIFontDescriptor.TraitKey.weight, so keep an eye out for them in future betas.

Rens
2022-06-09 00:16:36

*Thread Reply:* Great, thanks. Are the float values for the width described anywhere?

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:17:07

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:17:28

*Thread Reply:* ‚Ä¶or probably more useful, https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uifontdescriptor/traitkey/1616684-width

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:17:40

*Thread Reply:* > The valid value range is from -1.0 to 1.0. The value of 0.0 corresponds to the regular glyph spacing.

2022-06-09 00:16:04

@Lowell asked > Would you be able to share some insight on how the various Collection Views are implemented within the Calendar app? The paging that goes on endlessly is something I have been trying to recreate for a while but it's tricky. Any hints would be greatly appreciated :)

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:16:14

*Thread Reply:* You can achieve endless scrolling by essentially adding and removing sections while scrolling and making sure to adjust the content offset when doing so. UIScrollView (and thus UICollectionView) will keep its inertia and make it look seamless. If you have specific use cases this might be a great thing to discuss in a 1on1 lab.

üî• Artyom
Lowell
2022-06-09 00:18:04

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:16:55

@Jonathan asked > iOS 16 offers a great new API addition in the way of UIHostingConfiguration for rendering SwiftUI views in List CollectionView cells, however we‚Äôd love to support this type of interop on iOS 15 too. ‚Ä®When using UIHostingControllers in UICollectionView list cells, is there any specific considerations that should be taken into account in addition to managing cell reuse issues?

üéâ Romy
Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:17:09

*Thread Reply:* Unfortunately there isn‚Äôt an officially supported way to use SwiftUI inside of UIKit cells prior to iOS 16. Embedding a UIHostingController inside of cells is not recommended.

Lior
2022-06-09 00:18:28

*Thread Reply:* Just to be clear, it's not recommended due to performance issues, right?

‚úÖ Romy
Jonathan
2022-06-09 00:18:56

*Thread Reply:* @Tyler F (Apple) This is great to know, thank you! Is there any further light you can shed on why? As Lior comments, I am guessing due to performance overhead or reuse pitfalls?

Romy
2022-06-09 00:19:48

*Thread Reply:* i love this new feature!!!!

‚ù§Ô∏è Tyler F (Apple)
Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:27:19

*Thread Reply:* While performance is certainly a concern, the main issue is really around the nature of needing to embed a view controller (the UIHostingController) in each cell. Generally speaking, putting view controllers inside cells is discouraged in UIKit. This is because of how cell reuse works, as well as the way information propagates through the view controller and view hierarchy in UIKit. So using UIHostingController in cells creates problems and can result in some surprising bugs. (A common example we‚Äôve seen are issues with safe area information propagating into SwiftUI.) These are all things that the new UIHostingConfiguration API addresses!

üôè Romy, Leonard, Artyom
Lowell
2022-06-09 00:31:18

*Thread Reply:* TIL

Jonathan
2022-06-09 00:31:27

*Thread Reply:* Makes complete sense. So glad to see the new UIHostingConfiguration API and we'll be eager to adopt it once our minimum version is 16! Thanks to you and team for your hard work.

‚úÖ Romy
Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:36:39

*Thread Reply:* Despite that advice not to use UIHostingController in cells, provided that you are using the supported UIHostingConfiguration API starting with iOS 16, if you are able to get something working with UIHostingController on previous iOS versions and you have tested it well enough yourself that you know it works and meets your needs, you can probably get away with that because UIKit & SwiftUI aren‚Äôt changing anymore on those older iOS versions. And since you‚Äôre using UIHostingConfiguration going forward, you won‚Äôt run into any new issues with the unsupported UIHostingController implementation in the future. But again, this is not officially supported, so you are on your own, and you need to thoroughly test to make sure you can find an implementation that works well enough.

üôå Romy, Artyom
üëç Jonathan, Tyler
Lukas
2022-06-09 00:37:44

*Thread Reply:* @Tyler F (Apple) would these concerns also apply to general usage of UIHostingControllers for leaf node views, like buttons? VC pattern would generally not be used there in pure UIKit world, and UIHostingControllers force us into it. Are there perf concerns? Is leaf node SwiftUI in UIKit discouraged, or is it okay if we properly add the VCs in the VC hierarchy?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:38:46

*Thread Reply:* Not really, the specific issues mentioned above are really about having view controllers inside cells (inside of a UIScrollView), due to cell reuse and scrolling performance.

üëç Lukas

2022-06-09 00:47:29

2022-06-09 00:49:49

ü§£ Romy
Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:56:25

*Thread Reply:* Feedback requests are greatly appreciated üôè

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:48:59

@Klemen asked > Documentation mentions UITextView in iOS16 uses TextKit 2. I‚Äôve managed to disable word wrap via textContainer.widthTracksTextView = false and setting the textContainer.size to a value wider than the view‚Äôs bounds, but looks like UITextView still doesn‚Äôt support horizontal scrolling, nor it tracks the cursor. Is that something that‚Äôs expected to work, or not yet?

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:49:30

*Thread Reply:* If I‚Äôm understanding you correctly, I don‚Äôt believe that this is intended to be supported. Did it used to work for you with TextKit 1?

Klemen
2022-06-09 00:50:07

*Thread Reply:* No, but I was under the impression that the new TextKit engine is going to support it.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:50:30

*Thread Reply:* I suspect you have good reasons why you‚Äôre not doing this, but if you need a one-line text input (no wrapping, scrolls) UITextField is your class.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:52:16

*Thread Reply:* You could likely set up a UITextView to not scroll and be at your desired width, then place it inside a UIScrollView - but you would not get any sort of autoscrolling.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:56:50

*Thread Reply:* ‚Ä¶but you could scroll yourself by setting content offset when the text view‚Äôs reports to its delegate that the selection has changed. (Obviously your question is still rolling around in my head üôÇ)

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:57:12

*Thread Reply:* If this is something you really need and are unable to accomplish reasonably, feedback is always appreciated (https://developer.apple.com/bug-reporting/).

Apple Developer
Bug Reporting - Apple Developer
Now with Feedback Assistant available on iPhone, iPad, Mac, and the web, it‚Äôs easier to submit effective bug reports and request enhancements to APIs and tools.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/bug-reporting/
Klemen
2022-06-09 01:04:17

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd like the content to overflow beyond the view‚Äôs bounds, without wrapping text, which is preferred in plain text (fixed-width font) editors (code editor, markdown, etc). Think of it as a soft-wrap feature, where the UITextView on an iPhone screen or a windowed iPad app is actually narrower and doesn‚Äôt fit the 80-column text content.

I noticed that the NSTextContainer allows for a wider content than the viewport‚Äôs size, but the UITextView doesn‚Äôt seem to implement auto-scrolling, as the caret moves beyond the text view‚Äôs visible area.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:14:59

*Thread Reply:* Makes sense. You could try implementing UITextViewDelegate.textViewDidChangeSelection(_:) and calling setContentOffset with the result of something calculated from caretRectForPosition: or the like (note that UITextView implements all of UITextInput, which has a bunch of methods about geometry).

But you‚Äôre definitely doing something that is not in the designed-for use cases.

Klemen
2022-06-09 01:20:03

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the suggestion, I just tried it, but it seems that the widthTracksTextView is not supported on iOS/iPadOS. As soon as the UITextView ‚Äôs frame changes its size, the textCointainer‚Äôs size is set and the lines are wrapped.

I also filed the suggestion: FB10115560

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:23:46

*Thread Reply:* Ah - yeah, you‚Äôre right. We override those based on the ‚ÄôscrollEnabled

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:23:49

*Thread Reply:* ' state.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:24:26

*Thread Reply:* I will return to my ‚Äònon-scrollable text view inside a scroll view‚Äô suggestion then. But I realize it‚Äôs clunky.

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:24:39

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for filing the feedback!

‚ù§Ô∏è Klemen

2022-06-09 01:30:21

Steven
2022-06-09 01:30:44

Raleigh L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:30:51

*Thread Reply:* NSFilePromiseReceiver is pretty nice because it's compatible with any code using the other techniques

Steven
2022-06-09 01:32:49

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:20:45

@Anil Abraham asked > With UIActivityViewController, is it possible to provide multiple representations of the same object (a URL and text, e.g., through an NSItemProvider) as well as LPLinkMetadata? > > UIActivityItemsConfigurationReading is the only way I've gotten the NSItemProvider to work, but that doesn't support link metadata. And UIActivityItemSource supports the metadata, but not the item provider.

Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:23:17

*Thread Reply:* You can provide link metadata using UIActivityItemsConfigurationReading by implementing the activityItemsConfigurationMetadata(key:) function, and watching for the linkPresentationMetadata key.

Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:23:57

*Thread Reply:* Remember also that you have the option of using the prebuilt UIActivityItemsConfiguration class, which has properties that you can set for these metadata.

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:31:47

*Thread Reply:* When I return LPLinkMetadata from the UIActivityItemsConfiguration.metadataProvider closure, it doesn't use the image, title, or subtitle in the metadata

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:32:15

*Thread Reply:* Strike that, the metadataProvider closure is never even called with the linkPresentationMetadata key

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:46:30

*Thread Reply:* @Dave R (Apple) I've filed FB10116030 about this

Dave R (Apple)
2022-06-09 03:03:55

*Thread Reply:* Thank you. I‚Äôll take a look.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:32:20

@Anil Abraham asked > With the new self-sizing cells, is there a way to run an animation alongside a cell resize animation (or at least, adding a custom completion handler to the system-provided resize animation)?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:32:45

*Thread Reply:* With the new selfSizingInvalidation feature (aka ‚Äúself-resizing cells‚Äù), when a cell is resized with animation, the cell will also receive a full layout pass as part of the same animation. This means that any layout changes to subviews inside the cell‚Äôs contentView will also animate by default alongside the resizing of the cell itself.

There isn‚Äôt an explicit way to manually attach animations to that resize animation when it‚Äôs initiated directly by a cell via invalidateIntrinsicContentSize ‚Äî do you have something specific in mind you‚Äôre trying to do?

üëç Anil Abraham
Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:34:23

*Thread Reply:* You can of course continue to use the apply method on diffable data source (re-applying the current snapshot), or performBatchUpdates on the collection/table view directly if you are not using a diffable data source, to resize visible cells as you would prior to iOS 16. And both of those APIs do provide a completion handler you can use.

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:43:42

*Thread Reply:* I've got a text view that I'm hiding/showing that I want to appear to progressively expand as the cell grows. I've had some trouble doing this previously with the old beginUpdates/endUpdates, but it sounds like it should be doable with the self-resizing cells stuff

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:45:37

*Thread Reply:* Relatedly, the text view is in a stack view and the cell isn't automatically detecting the change when isHidden is changed on the text view (which should, AIUI, cause the stack view to change its internal constraints which should count as an auto layout change). I have to call invalidateIntrinsicContentSize myself to get the size to update. Could that be something on my end, or is it more likely a framework bug?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:52:42

*Thread Reply:* > I‚Äôve got a text view that I‚Äôm hiding/showing that I want to appear to progressively expand as the cell grows. I‚Äôve had some trouble doing this previously with the old beginUpdates/endUpdates, but it sounds like it should be doable with the self-resizing cells stuff The new self-resizing cells functionality does work great with multiline UITextView (scrollEnabled = false) inside of the cell contentView, when you want the cell to size-to-fit the text view as more text is added!

I‚Äôm still not sure what you had in mind around adding alongside animations or completions though.

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:55:59

*Thread Reply:* > Relatedly, the text view is in a stack view and the cell isn‚Äôt automatically detecting the change when isHidden is changed on the text view (which should, AIUI, cause the stack view to change its internal constraints which should count as an auto layout change). I have to call invalidateIntrinsicContentSize myself to get the size to update. Could that be something on my end, or is it more likely a framework bug? If you have an easy place to call invalidateIntrinsicContentSize yourself, that‚Äôs actually the best option in general combined with the default selfSizingInvalidation = .enabled . The .enabledIncludingConstraints mode can be more expensive, as it requires checking for size changes on any Auto Layout constraint changes.

But based on your description this does sound like something that is supposed to work automatically when you have set .enabledIncludingConstraints , so if you don‚Äôt see any obvious issues on your end, it would be great if you could submit a Feedback report with a small sample project attached for us to take a look at! https://feedbackassistant.apple.com

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:58:22

*Thread Reply:* It's not adding/removing text from the view that I'm doing, but hiding it wholesale. And since it's in a stack view, it was getting removed from the view hierarchy altogether‚Äîwithout being animated, so I thought I'd need a custom animation to cover that up. Now I'm thinking it would work better to add a constraint setting the height to 0 to "hide" it without removing it, and thus letting it animate

Anil Abraham
2022-06-09 01:59:26

*Thread Reply:* I can stick to calling that method myself, it's pretty easy to do, I was just hoping for a little magic, lol. I'll try to drum up a sample project for a feedback that repros the issue, though

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 16:57:51

*Thread Reply:* Gotcha ‚Äî and yes a sample project would be great!

Tyler
2022-06-09 18:14:24

*Thread Reply:* ‚Äú‚Ä¶when a cell is resized with animation, the cell will also receive a full layout pass as part of the same animation.‚Äù Is this true for updates via performBatchUpdates as well? My recollection is that there were issues around the cell view instance getting swapped out which would end up killing the animation within the cell. Are cell views always preserved across empty batch updates, or am I misremembering?

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:16:13

*Thread Reply:* > My recollection is that there were issues around the cell view instance getting swapped out which would end up killing the animation within the cell. Are cell views always preserved across empty batch updates, or am I misremembering? For empty batch updates, as well as the new iOS 16 self-sizing invalidation feature, the existing cells won‚Äôt be replaced or reused. Only when using the reload API to reload an item/section will the cell get replaced with a new one.

üôå Tyler
Tyler
2022-06-09 18:16:51

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Tyler!

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:17:01

*Thread Reply:* (Don‚Äôt forget about the reconfigure API introduced in iOS 15 to update cells without replacing them, too!)

üëç Tyler
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:38:13

@Chang asked > Is there a way to get a notification when a new item (e.g. image) is added to UIPasteboard remotely (e.g. through Universal Clipboard). Currently I can poll changeCount to detect changes, but I receive no changedNotification unless the copy originated from the app itself. I'm trying to implement a feature where the app conveniently offers a paste button when there's something on the UIPasteboard.

:gratitude_thank_you: Roman
üëç Roman
Roman
2022-06-09 01:42:38

*Thread Reply:* That would've been handy.

We do the same but with users' texts, suggesting them a button that Creates document right from the pasteboard.

But it probably doesn't work with universal clipboard. I'm not sure if it works for us in the iPad split view, but I assume we check pasteboard everytime our app becomes active.

However, AFAIK, it is not possible with universal clipboard

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:42:57

*Thread Reply:* We generally discourage polling the pasteboard in any way, it can be resource-intensive. However, feel free to request a public notification for when the pasteboard changes, you can check for item count + metadata w/o triggering the paste alert.

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:43:34

*Thread Reply:* The new paste button does enable/disable itself when the something appears on the pasteboard though.

Roman
2022-06-09 01:44:35

*Thread Reply:* Hmm, is it customizable? Would be grateful for a link on the session about that )

Chang
2022-06-09 01:45:13

*Thread Reply:* ‚ÄúHowever, feel free to request a public notification for when the pasteboard change‚Äù. Is there an API to do this? Did you mean I should file a feedback?

Chang
2022-06-09 01:47:03

*Thread Reply:* Also, there seems to be an issue where the UIPasteboard.general.changeCount gets incremented by two every time I start editing a text view (without copying anything)

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:48:11

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10068?time=683

Apple Developer
What's new in UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover the latest updates and improvements to UIKit and learn how to build better iPadOS, iOS, and Mac Catalyst apps. We'll take you...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10068?time=683
:gratitude_thank_you: Roman
Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:48:38

*Thread Reply:* > Did you mean I should file a feedback? Yes.

Chang
2022-06-09 01:49:46

*Thread Reply:* ‚Äúyou can check for item count + metadata w/o triggering the paste alert.‚Äù When you said metadata, are there any existing ones I can look at (to detect duplicates) without showing the alert?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:50:32

*Thread Reply:* Re: changeCount, we don't guarantee that it will increment +1 each time. Multiple processes etc. may end up bumping it up more.

Chang
2022-06-09 01:51:15

*Thread Reply:* I see

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:51:53

*Thread Reply:* metadata = types of items. So e.g. -[UIPasteboard hasStrings] is a metadata query, but -[UIPasteboard strings] is a data query.

Chang
2022-06-09 01:53:31

*Thread Reply:* So, assuming I want to detect when a new image is pasted elsewhere‚Ä¶ hasStrings will not change (already true), and changeCount is an unreliable way of detecting new ones. So I‚Äôm basically out of luck‚Ä¶

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:53:35

*Thread Reply:* You can also run pattern detection w/o triggering the paste alert, so e.g. looking for URL's and addresses via detectPatternsForPatterns:completionHandler:. This is also considered metadata and won't trigger the alert.

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:54:48

*Thread Reply:* changeCount will get incremented with a new image

Chang
2022-06-09 01:56:20

*Thread Reply:* ‚ÄúchangeCount will get incremented with a new image‚Äù. Yes, I‚Äôm observing that. However since changeCount gets incremented no matter what the type of the content is, it seems like I cannot get a image-specific changeCount, is that correct?

Glen L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:58:30

*Thread Reply:* You can check if the data is an image and the change count is incremented.

Chang
2022-06-09 02:00:16

*Thread Reply:* You‚Äôre right! I have a bug in my code ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Thanks!

2022-06-09 17:00:21

Welcome to the SwiftUI/UIKit/AppKit Q&A! We have many Apple engineers here from all of these frameworks eager to answer your questions.

In this Q&A, we‚Äôre specifically focusing on questions about using SwiftUI together with UIKit and AppKit.

To ask a question, click the‚ûïicon on the lower left, and choose the ‚ÄúAsk a question‚Äù workflow. Type your question and submit it. We‚Äôll answer as many questions as we can, but if we don‚Äôt get to yours, rest assured that we do read every question and we truly appreciate you taking the time to ask yours!

Let‚Äôs get started! üöÄ

2022-06-09 17:03:05

@Mike asked > Does SwiftUI support the new toolbar modes for iPad or do you need to use UIKit?

Harry L (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:07:08

*Thread Reply:* It does!

Check out the toolbar role API: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/view/toolbarrole(_:)

And the secondary action toolbar item placement: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/toolbaritemplacement/secondaryaction

For more information, I go into these APIs in the 2 part of SwiftUI on iPad series: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10058 https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10058

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:07:02

@Majid asked > Hello, should we approach SwiftUI views as data models for real views? Where should we place data formatting logic? If SwiftUI view is a data model we can data formatting logic there? How can we test our data formatting logic in this case?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:08:22

*Thread Reply:* The most convenient way to unit test your data formatting logic (like a Foundation FormatStyle) will be to factor the formatter out and assert against the String it produces

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:09:13

*Thread Reply:* I generally wouldn't consider a SwiftUI view to be a data model

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:09:33

*Thread Reply:* Factoring out the formatter might take the form of lifting into a model or view model

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:09:59

*Thread Reply:* Or it might just take the form of specifying it in a computed property on the View and running the assertion against that

Majid
2022-06-09 17:11:04

*Thread Reply:* So, we can use property testing to assert data formatting directly inside SwiftUI Views. Is it good practice? How do you deal with this problem at Apple in big projects?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:14:07

*Thread Reply:* Unit testing is a bit of an art and so I wouldn't say it's a necessarily a good or bad practice to assert directly against the SwiftUI view.

I think the concerns are more pragmatic: how easy is it to assert against the SwiftUI view vs against a model. Does one way or the other require extra boilerplate? Does one way or the other lead to fewer false negatives?

Majid
2022-06-09 17:16:21

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Kyle for your answers üôå

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:07:32

@Pavan asked > Does this new APIs are backward comaptible with UIKit project or just only iOS 16?

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:08:23

*Thread Reply:* In general all APIs that are introduced in new versions of our operating systems always require those versions to be used. However you can conditionalize your code to only use those new features when running on that OS and have your app back deploy to old versions without those features.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:09:44

*Thread Reply:* Ok got it, but it might double the implementation and maintenance

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:25:40

*Thread Reply:* That, unfortunately, is a technical limitation. These features are implemented in frameworks that are shipping with the OS and that are heavily integrated with the OS, so they require the new OS to work. In a lot of cases you can just add the new features when running on the new OS and just do nothing on older versions, in which case it is enough to just check the current version you are running at run time before calling out to the new APIs.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:36:37

*Thread Reply:* Ok got it thanks, I think we might need to wait until next two years lol üòÑ

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:08:02

@Yi Ju asked > What‚Äôs the naming convention you‚Äôd recommend using for a SwiftUI view - with or without View suffix? I think I‚Äôve seen both in Apple examples.

üíØ Maximilian
‚ûï Andrew
Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:08:12

*Thread Reply:* A good rule of thumb is that if the name we are picking has a clear visual representation, say Text, Image, Toggle, we omit the view suffix.

In cases like ProgressView where Progress really would feel more like the data itself than its visual representation we add the View suffix. Specifically in the case of Progress we would clash with Foundation.Progress which will require developer to always fully qualify the type name which is not ideal.

üôå Karim-Pierre, Muthuveerappan, Joseph, Felix, Anant J (Apple), Yi Ju, Yunson, Cristi, Vidunan, Leonard, Tyler, Erik
üëç Malek, Cristian-Mihai, Andres, Denis, Vidunan
Clint
2022-06-09 17:09:39

*Thread Reply:* How does one ask a new question in this channel? I don't see a way to do it.

Yi Ju
2022-06-09 17:09:54

*Thread Reply:* That makes a lot of sense, thank you Luca!

‚ò∫Ô∏è Luca B (Apple)
Christian
2022-06-09 17:10:25

*Thread Reply:* Clint ‚Äì click the + in the bottom left and select ‚ÄúAsk a question‚Äù:

image.png

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:09:30

@Artyom asked > Once again, here goes the question about SwiftUI views in Table/Collection cell. üòÅ > If we'd like to tinker with our own UIHostingConfiguration to support older OS versions, what would be the recommended way to update cell's height when used with DiffableDataSource? > Currently, the most common scenario I see is a pair of > tableView.beginUpdates() > tableView.endUpdates() > > It would be nice to recap on our available options.

Tyler F (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:09:39

*Thread Reply:* On iOS 15 and earlier, you request an update to the size of self-sizing cells in UICollectionView and UITableView by: ‚Ä¢ If using diffable data source, re-applying the diffable data source‚Äôs current snapshot with animatingDifferences: true ‚Ä¢ If not using diffable data source, performing empty batch updates on the collection or table view directly (that‚Äôs the same as the begin/end updates you mentioned)

Artyom
2022-06-09 17:10:27

*Thread Reply:* Got it, thanks!

Paul B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:30:54

*Thread Reply:* There is not a way to do this at the moment. Thanks for filing (and referencing) the feedback, we will route it to the appropriate component!

@Sone√© asked > We've experiencing a watchdog termination in the background due to a function inside UIKit sleeping. Please see the following backtrace: > > &gt; Thread 0 Crashed: &gt; 0 libsystem_kernel.dylib 0x00000002065bba2c __semwait_signal + 8 &gt; 1 libsystem_c.dylib 0x00000001d9c700e4 nanosleep + 220 (nanosleep.c:104) &gt; 5 UIKitCore 0x00000001d1243b90 -[_UIContextBinder purgeContextsWithPurgeAction:afterPurgeAction:] + 472 (_UIContextBinder.m:221) &gt; 6 UIKitCore 0x00000001d12874ec -[UIWindowScene _prepareForSuspend] + 88 (UIWindowScene.m:1271) &gt; 7 UIKitCore 0x00000001d1ec935c __130-[UIApplication _updateStateRestorationArchiveForBackgroundEvent:saveState:exitIfCouldNotRestoreState:updateSnapshot:windowScene:]_block_invoke_2 + 228 (UIApplication.m:11237) &gt; 8 UIKitCore 0x00000001d128e4dc -[_UIAfterCACommitBlock run] + 72 (_UIAfterCACommitQueue.m:137) &gt; 9 UIKitCore 0x00000001d11a1864 -[_UIAfterCACommitQueue flush] + 192 (_UIAfterCACommitQueue.m:228) &gt; 10 libdispatch.dylib 0x00000001ce7eae6c _dispatch_call_block_and_release + 32 (init.c:1517) &gt; 11 libdispatch.dylib 0x00000001ce7eca30 _dispatch_client_callout + 20 (object.m:560) &gt; 12 libdispatch.dylib 0x00000001ce7faf48 _dispatch_main_queue_drain + 928 (inline_internal.h:2622) &gt; 13 libdispatch.dylib 0x00000001ce7fab98 _dispatch_main_queue_callback_4CF + 44 (queue.c:7770) &gt; 14 CoreFoundation 0x00000001ceb3d800 __CFRUNLOOP_IS_SERVICING_THE_MAIN_DISPATCH_QUEUE__ + 16 (CFRunLoop.c:1795) &gt; 15 CoreFoundation 0x00000001ceaf7704 __CFRunLoopRun + 2532 (CFRunLoop.c:3144) &gt; 16 CoreFoundation 0x00000001ceb0abc8 CFRunLoopRunSpecific + 600 (CFRunLoop.c:3268) &gt; 17 GraphicsServices 0x00000001eac3e374 GSEventRunModal + 164 (GSEvent.c:2200) &gt; 18 UIKitCore 0x00000001d147a648 -[UIApplication _run] + 1100 (UIApplication.m:3511) &gt; 19 UIKitCore 0x00000001d11fbd90 UIApplicationMain + 364 (UIApplication.m:5064) &gt; 20 [REDACTED] 0x0000000104e87460 main + 112 (main.m:27) &gt; 21 dyld 0x00000001055e5ce4 start + 520 (dyldMain.cpp:879) &gt;

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:10:46

*Thread Reply:* Hi there! This looks like a potentially issue in CoreAnimation. If you haven't already, can you file a feedback with the entire crash log?

Sone√©
2022-06-09 17:11:10

*Thread Reply:* Sure thing. Thanks! üôÇ

Steve M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:13:04

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:05

*Thread Reply:* Apps generally have around 5 seconds to stop processing when they‚Äôre backgrounded. If an app is still ‚Äòalive‚Äô and doing things at that point, it will be terminated to preserve system responsiveness.

In this 5 seconds, we usually reconfigure your apps interface multiple times (rotating, switching to light/dark mode etc.) to take screenshots to use in the application switcher UI.

What might be happening here is that your app is taking a long time to lay out for these screenshots. It may be finishing in just under five seconds - then this system code (which frees up memory used by CA that‚Äôs not necessary while your app has nothing on screen) runs - and during that we hit the timeout.

If your crash trace has a ‚Äútermination reason‚Äù that mentions ‚Äúwatchdog‚Äù that‚Äôs an indication that this might be happening.

‚ù§Ô∏è Herman
Jamie M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:13

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for reading my novel.

üòÜ Andres, Leonard, Bishwa
üëç Denis
Leonard
2022-06-09 18:12:10

*Thread Reply:* @Jamie M (Apple) That's super interesting! I never considered how much work goes into creating screenshots for the app switcher

‚ù§Ô∏è Herman
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:11:01

@Muthuveerappan asked > My doubt is regarding drag and drop on SwiftUI > I think there are 2 approaches but I am stuck with both the approaches > > WWDC22 > - When using the new draggable, dropDestination, Transferable API, I am only able to drag single items. I am unable to drag multiple items in a list. I have filed a feedback FB10128110 > > WWDC21 > - I have faced a couple of issues for drag and drop introduced in WWDC21 (onDrag, onDrop, itemIdentifier), the Feedback ids are FB9854301, FB9854569, FB9855245, FB9855532, FB9855567, FB9855575. > > Note: All feedbacks include a sample project with detail steps and some even have screenshots and videos > > Please let me know me if my approach is wrong or if I am missing something. > Unfortunately I didn't manage to get a SwiftUI lab session (got declined), so any assistance on the above would be much appreciated

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:15:26

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Muthuveerappan! First, thank you for filing the radars! Getting feedback on the new APIs and knowing which enhancements are anticipated is important. For now, I have one pointer that could be useful: for Lists and ForEach, we expect you to use the onInsert modifier. onDrag is designed for other types of views.

üôè Muthuveerappan
Javier
2022-06-09 17:18:58

*Thread Reply:* FYI, onInsert on a Table with 0 rows did not work last year (FB9265795) on macOS, it seems the problem persists this year with macOS. Haven‚Äôt test it in iOS, which now supports Tables too.

üëç Muthuveerappan
Muthuveerappan
2022-06-09 17:20:03

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:22:14

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I was talking about last year APIs. draggable is new this year, analogous to onDrag and making use of Transferable

@Lowell asked > Are there any major limitations to be aware of with the new UIHostingConfiguration for collection view cells using SwiftUI, that may not be addressed in the session video?

2022-06-09 17:16:05

Apple Developer
Use SwiftUI with UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how to take advantage of the power of SwiftUI in your UIKit app. Build custom UICollectionView and UITableView cells seamlessly...

Lowell
2022-06-09 17:16:45

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:15:46

@Yugantar asked > I was wondering if we can use the SwiftUI View protocol with the new 'any' keyword? And if it'll be helpful or a good solution in some example use-case?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:16:08

*Thread Reply:* any View does not itself conform to View, so is not a replacement for AnyView today. Also any View is only defining an existential container that you can use in a type signature but you can‚Äôt instantiate that type.

There might be use cases for using any View to store that into collection, for example: [any View]. But most of the time, if you‚Äôre in the situation where you think you need [AnyView] or [any View], what you should likely do is invert the view dependency flow and have [AnyDataModel] or [any DataModel] instead, then create your views based on the type of data provided at runtime.

Yugantar
2022-06-09 17:16:46

*Thread Reply:* Great, thank you for the detailed explanation!

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:18:28

*Thread Reply:* You are welcome! Was your question based on a concrete problem you are trying to solve?

Yugantar
2022-06-09 17:20:32

*Thread Reply:* No, I just watched the Embrace Generics session today and this question immediately popped to mind üôÇ

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:15:49

@Pavan asked > We have compositional layout with CollectionView and content is coming from remote including image so based on the image height we adjust the height of the cells, so until we determine the height of the image we have ideal height, but the problem is user can keep scrolling down while images are getting downloaded cells are drawn with ideal height but when image get downloaded we fix the height for the cell during which we see collection view jitters/jump up down due to content size changes > Any ways to improve this?

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:19:16

*Thread Reply:* Here is the video

IIPB-14444.mov
Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:19:50

*Thread Reply:* Hi Pavan, there are a few different strategies you can take here, depending on how you‚Äôre updating your cells. What you‚Äôll want to do is to apply a content offset to the scroll view that is the inverse of the increase in the size from cells above the currently visible area. This would need to be performed synchronously, however. The details here depend on the specifics of your layout definition, though.

Another alternative is to use .estimated for your item definitions, Then, if their size changes, UICollectionView will automatically adjust the content offset to preserve the semantic scroll position.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:23:35

*Thread Reply:* Hi Aditya, yes we are using estimated height and the above results with that, so what we are doing once we get actual size we are reloading the section to determine the actual height but during which content size changes hence collection view jumps

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:23:57

*Thread Reply:* I didn‚Äôt understand the inversion logic you said, sorry

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:26:47

*Thread Reply:* Ah, reloading the section. That is unfortunately a known issue with UICollectionView currently, where we don‚Äôt preserve the scroll position when items/sections are reloaded.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:27:59

*Thread Reply:* I see, do you think this could be solved in SwiftUI using ScrollView + LazyVStack?

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:29:19

*Thread Reply:* Any other recommendation is to improve this UI will be great help since this just works fine in android where our customers complaints for iOS üòû

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:29:27

*Thread Reply:* Have you tried reconfiguring the individual items instead? Use either the reconfigure method on diffable data source, https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/nsdiffabledatasourcesnapshot/3804468-reconfigureitems

or UICollectionView.reconfigureItems(at:) : https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uicollectionview/3801889-reconfigureitems

reloading performs a delete + insert

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:31:08

*Thread Reply:* hmm i see, but our app supports from iOS 13 but this API looks like from iOS 15.0 unfortunately

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:37:23

*Thread Reply:* Prior to iOS 15, you can update the contents of the cells directly (by fetching them from UICollectionView.cellForItem(at:), and call performBatchUpdates: with an empty block to update their visible sizes.

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:38:19

*Thread Reply:* Cells that are off screen, or not currently prepared for display (like prefetched cells) will return nil from cellForItem(at:) , and you can just specify the full-size image when they‚Äôre dequeued the next time.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:42:20

*Thread Reply:* > Cells that are off screen, or not currently prepared for display (like prefetched cells) will return nil from cellForItem(at:) , and you can just specify the full-size image when they‚Äôre dequeued the next time. Do i need to return nil for this specific case?

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:42:46

*Thread Reply:* > Prior to iOS 15, you can update the contents of the cells directly (by fetching them from UICollectionView.cellForItem(at:), and call performBatchUpdates: with an empty block to update So with this approach will collection view preserves the scroll offset?

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:47:02

*Thread Reply:* No, you‚Äôd be calling cellForItem(at:) on the UICollectionView, so it will return nil if a prepared cell does not currently exist.

> So with this approach will collection view preserves the scroll offset? Yes! That should preserve the scroll offset.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:54:00

*Thread Reply:* aha it‚Äôs just like below? ```psuedo code // loop over cells let cell = UICollectionView.cellForItem(at:...) cell.image.height = xxx

// Call performBatchUpdates collectionView.performBatchUpdates { <empty> }```

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:56:40

*Thread Reply:* yep! That should work! Definitely encourage you to try it out.

Pavan
2022-06-09 17:56:59

2022-06-09 17:58:09

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:16:31

@Jan asked > Using ShareLink in SwiftUI and Transferable, we will now be able to share custom types between users. How does this compare to sharing Core Data entities using a .shared CloudKit database? As I understand, the main difference is that sharing using Transferable copies the item from User A and pastes it for User B, so in the end there will be 2 instances of this item, with no synchronization. Any subsequent changes to any of the items will remain local for that user. In contrast, sharing using .shared CloudKit database means a single entity will be synchronized for both users. Am I on the right track? Are there some other key differences to be aware of?

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:31

*Thread Reply:* Hi Jan!

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:37

*Thread Reply:* > How does this compare to sharing Core Data entities using a .shared CloudKit database? There is a difference: ShareLink is used for sharing here and now, not for persistent storage. Core Data is a database‚Äìand its intended use is for storing items on the disk.

> As I understand, the main difference is that sharing using Transferable copies the item from User A and pastes it for User B It depends on which transport APIs we are using. For example, Drag and Drop allows sharing items within a single process or between different processes. Copy/paste works similarly.

If we are using FileRepresentation, we can specify the allowAccessingOriginalFile parameter for SentTransferredFiles and tell the system if should make the copy, or not.

Transferable doesn‚Äôt provide any synchronization, just passes around data.

Jan
2022-06-09 17:43:29

*Thread Reply:* Thank you @Julia V (Apple)! So in a use case where we are sharing persistent data between users of the same app (for example, a recipe created by the user in a recipe app), is using ShareLink discouraged in favour of sharing using Core Data + CloudKit?

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:46:23

*Thread Reply:* I wouldn‚Äôt say discouraged, it just has different purpose. ShareLink allows to present the share sheet or another system sharing interface, so users could send over the recipes to their friends in Messages, or pasted into Notes, etc. Does this make sense?

Jan
2022-06-09 17:47:55

*Thread Reply:* Yes I think so - in this case, the recipe would have to be converted to something Messages/Notes can understand, like String or Image. Right?

üëÄ Ryan
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:24:45

*Thread Reply:* Yes this is an explicit use case the Layout protocol was designed to support

John H (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:24:56

*Thread Reply:* Yes, that should be fine, although you'll need to manage the cache(s) of any intermediate layouts you use. (E.g. store them in your own layout's cache storage, and invalidate them as needed.)

üëÜ Kyle M (Apple)
John H (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:25:27

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:24:56

@Cristian-Mihai asked > Hi there! What's the recommended way to repeatedly fetch data in a SwiftUI app, (so that we don't push updates from a different thread)?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:25:14

*Thread Reply:* In general, I would suggest to factor out the logic that fetches the data into its own type. You always want to execute this kind of side effect not on the main thread and the hop back onto the main thread to set the data on the model.

Swift‚Äôs actors are a great tool to encapsulate this kind of logic. So for example you could the model that is offered to the view be an ObservableObject that is bound to the main actor, and have a separate actor (hence running on a separate thread) that takes care of the fetching and report back new data to your observable object.

Matthias
2022-06-09 17:26:56

*Thread Reply:* do you have an example of that?

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 17:27:18

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! In my case, I had a model that conformed to ObservableObject, but somehow I still got the warning. Will look into it though!

Thomas
2022-06-09 17:30:14

*Thread Reply:* I would like to see sample code for this. Words do not describe the nuts and bolts of coding.....

Jan
2022-06-09 17:30:43

*Thread Reply:* I think conformance to ObservableObject is not the issue here. What you want is for your function to be wrapped in the Main actor, so updates to UI are pushed on the main thread: @MainActor func getData() {}

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 17:32:42

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I understood that the conformance to ObservableObject is not the problem, but rather the way I used to asynchronously fetch data to the model. Thanks!

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 17:33:26

*Thread Reply:* Here‚Äôs a link about Swift Actors that i just found: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10133/

Apple Developer
Protect mutable state with Swift actors - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Data races occur when two separate threads concurrently access the same mutable state. They are trivial to construct, but are notoriously...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10133/
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:26:20

@Maximilian asked > Would you use SwiftUI or UIKit to implement a list that can change layout between a table and grid layouts? I currently have a UICollectionView with different layouts but I can't animate between the layout change.

2022-06-09 17:27:31

Michael O (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:27:34

*Thread Reply:* As always we recommend using the tool that is best for the job. UICollectionView does support animating layout changes via setLayout:animated: so there is no need to rewrite this in SwiftUI. If there are specific things you want to achieve that can only be achieved in SwiftUI, then of course converting it to that is a very valid option.

2022-06-09 17:29:45

Aditya K (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:42:11

*Thread Reply:* Right, UICollectionView can‚Äôt currently animate changes to the layout stemming from an invalidation. If you require an animation, I would call setCollectionViewLayout(_:animated:completion:)

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:28:54

@Majid asked > Assume that I keep the whole app state in the state object in my app struct? This way I can make sure that all the views are in a consistent state and have a single source of truth. How can I tune performance because in this case, SwiftUI starts diffing the whole app view hierarchy on every single change of the app state?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:29:03

*Thread Reply:* You‚Äôre completely right that with a single observable object, you‚Äôll end up invalidating large parts of your view hierarchy whenever a change occurs. Invalidating even large amounts of the SwiftUI view hierarchy should be an inexpensive operation, as view descriptions are rather lightweight, but if you are running into performance issues here, there are a few things you can do to help. The first recommendation I have is to split out some of the values which are only relevant to a certain subset of views into their own observable object. This is likely going to get you the most performance win of any of these suggestions, but if you don‚Äôt want to make that architectural change, there are still some things you can do:

‚Ä¢ Avoid marking non-published values of your ObservableObject published ‚Ä¢ (Assuming you‚Äôre using EnvironmentObject to make sure your single StateObject can be accessed throughout your view hierarchy) ensuring you only declare dependencies on the EnvironmentObject in places it‚Äôs needed ‚Ä¢ And if you still need to optimize further, writing a custom objectWillChange implementation for your StateObjects which only does invalidation when changes that should actually affect the UI occur (in cases, for example, where published values have multiple different representations that should display in the same manner).

üëç Ruchish, Majid, Denis
Majid
2022-06-09 17:51:16

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Sam üëç

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:29:50

@Alexey asked > What is correct way to specify file type that allowed for Drag&Drop from Finder. I mean if I use UTType.fileURL it allows to Drop any type of files, but if I specify UTType.image that not allow Drop at all. What is correct approach if I want allow Drop only images from Finder?

Raleigh L (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:31:09

*Thread Reply:* Use the generic UTType.fileURL. And also override draggingEntered to inspect the exact file types on the pasteboard. Return true/false as appropriate.

Raleigh L (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:31

*Thread Reply:* Also when inspecting the pasteboard, use the options to auto filter the list for you. func readObjects( forClasses classArray: [AnyClass], options: [NSPasteboard.ReadingOptionKey : Any]? = nil ) -> [Any]?

Alexey
2022-06-09 17:35:15

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:49:11

*Thread Reply:* Let me chime in. DropInfo has a member called hasItemsConforming(to:) member, https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/dropinfo/hasitemsconforming(to:)-47irh, which allows to check for the content types you are interested in. Does this help?

Alexey
2022-06-09 17:52:43

*Thread Reply:* I try to use it, but unfortunately, it does not help in my case. Or maybe I just do something wrong. This method only checks the dropped content type. In my case it‚Äôs UTType.fileURL but it does not check is this an image or an mp4 file.

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:55:32

*Thread Reply:* Is it iOS or Mac?

Alexey
2022-06-09 17:55:37

*Thread Reply:* macOS

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:57:18

*Thread Reply:* Then the first idea on top of my head is to try to initialize NSImage with the URL/Data from the NSItemProvider and see if it succeeds.

Julia V (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:58:47

*Thread Reply:* If the app isn‚Äôt restricted to images from Finder only, you could register for receiving NSImage.imageTypes

Alexey
2022-06-09 18:01:55

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:31:22

@Ron asked > Is there a way to allow duplicate CommandMenu item .keyboardShortcuts? In AppKit macOS menus, this works, but not in SwiftUI. The duplicate shortcuts are never active at the same time - they depend on the type of the selection focus. (FB9931615)

üëç Austin
Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:31:43

*Thread Reply:* Assigning the same shortcut to different menu items is not recommended, even for AppKit apps.

The user should be able to predict the outcome of each shortcut. If the selection focus changes which menu item is invoked, that would be confusing.

Ron
2022-06-09 18:02:45

*Thread Reply:* The context (math vs text selection) is different enough to avoid confusion, but more importantly the change from AppKit to SwiftUI forces a UI change in the new app version which breaks current users muscle memory.

Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:07:20

*Thread Reply:* I see you've already filed feedback, thanks.

Nils B (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:09:55

*Thread Reply:* I don't suppose that the two different actions are similar enough that you could combine them into the same menu item, with the same shortcut? The Copy menu item is a good example of something that applies in a variety of different circumstances, and is strongly responder chain / focus driven...

Ron
2022-06-09 18:11:54

*Thread Reply:* In the one case where I had overloaded a shortcut, no. (Command-I for italics in text, as people are very used to. In math, formatting is determined by content, so there is no Italic action. Command-I was overloaded for Isolate, and had been for 30 years, even before the app supported text blocks at all. It is a very, very old application.)

Ron
2022-06-09 18:15:53

*Thread Reply:* I have rewritten 35 years of code in Swift and SwiftUI with the goal of maximum bug-for-bug compatibility. While there are inevitably going to be differences, I would like to make the transition as seamless as possible for users, many of whom have been using the software for decades.

Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:51:14

*Thread Reply:* Ron, in your AppKit version, did you use the same selector for each item that had a matching command key? I‚Äôm asking just to understand the approach that worked for you in the old codebase.

üö´ Ron
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:31:33

@Sarun asked > SwiftUI Layout isn't possible for dynamic content, right? Since each subview need to be there at calculation time.

üëÄ Jan
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:32:30

*Thread Reply:* It could depend what you mean by dynamic content

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:32:54

*Thread Reply:* The SwiftUI layouts you write yourself, like the system provided HStack and VStack, require all children up front

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:12

*Thread Reply:* However, often we use "dynamic" within the team to refer to content driven by a ForEach

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:27

*Thread Reply:* And that is absolutely supported with custom SwiftUI Layouts

üôå David
Ryan
2022-06-09 17:33:44

*Thread Reply:* If the subviews change size the layout should respond to those size changes.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:34:32

*Thread Reply:* The main thing that SwiftUI Layout doesn't support today is the lazy/incremental layouts that don't need to load all views up front

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:35:12

*Thread Reply:* There is not a way to build your own LazyHStack and LazyVStack on top of SwiftUI Layout... or at least not one that is as efficient in lazy loading content

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:36:14

*Thread Reply:* But as @Ryan alluded to, the SwiftUI framework automatically manages dependencies between views and will recall your layout's sizeThatFits or placeSubviews whenever anything needs to be recomputed (including child size changes)

Sarun
2022-06-09 17:39:00

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the answer, @Kyle M (Apple). I mean something like Lazy in my question, which you already answered üòÅ

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 17:39:18

*Thread Reply:* So, if the Layouts could‚Äôve been lazy, that means that the views in the Layout would‚Äôve been loaded only when needed (when they appeared on screen)? I‚Äôm asking this to make sure I understood the concept of lazy grids.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:44:10

*Thread Reply:* @Cristian-Mihai That's correct. A lazy Layout theoretically wouldn't have access to all of its children up front from sizeThatFits or placeSubviews, and so that limits some of the things it can calculate up front. Paul covers this well at the beginning of the "Compose custom layouts with SwiftUI" talk from yesterday: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10056/

Apple Developer
Compose custom layouts with SwiftUI - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
SwiftUI now offers powerful tools to level up your layouts and arrange views for your app's interface. We'll introduce you to the Grid...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10056/
Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 17:46:46

*Thread Reply:* Thank you very much for the clarification!

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:32:35

*Thread Reply:* If you want to be sure that the FetchRequest is setup before the view does any work you might want to set that up in the initializer.

I think it would be worth to file a feedback regarding the issue that you are seeing with onAppear.

Ratnesh
2022-06-09 17:33:27

*Thread Reply:* How to update FetchRequest for searchbar changes?

Jan
2022-06-09 17:34:07

*Thread Reply:* On this point in particular, I think we deserve a more SwiftUI-esque layer for communicating with Core Data. Turning the process of fetching data into a View is not very intuitive and breaks MVVM

Mike
2022-06-09 17:36:37

*Thread Reply:* Is there a best practice for Core Data and Swift UI app project on developer.apple.com?

Jan
2022-06-09 17:39:33

*Thread Reply:* @Ratnesh here I can help. You pass the searchValue to your view with FetchRequest. Then in the init, you add an NSPredicate specifying that only results that contain searchValue should be shown, and then create a FetchRequest with that predicate

‚ù§Ô∏è Ratnesh
Axel
2022-06-09 17:42:37

Do you confirm that the FetchRequest is reset when the containing View is redrawn? For example, if the SubView customises the predicate or sortDescriptor (in a context where the SubView apply some filters). The FetchRequest is not tied to the View lifecycle contrary to State or StateObject.

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:33:07

@Martin asked > In SwiftUI, is there a way to listen for navigation events or would that have to be custom from UIKit delegates?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:33:22

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the question, Martin.

With the new iOS 16 NavigationStack, you can bind a path to the stack. Then you can use the .onChange() modifier to watch for changes to the path.

üëç Matthias
üëç:skin_tone_4: Martin
David
2022-06-09 17:36:43

*Thread Reply:* What about non navigation events like dismissal of sheets or full screen modals? Is there a stateful way to be informed of when these events are done so we can say present a follow up confirmation or pop the navigation stack back?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:38:23

*Thread Reply:* Hey. David. Those dismiss events will reset the binding that caused the modal presentation to appear. So the same recommendation works there. You can use onChange() to observe that binding too.

David
2022-06-09 17:41:23

*Thread Reply:* What if you‚Äôre programmatically changing those bindings? If I set an isPresented var to false to dismiss a modal, how would I be able to know when the modal is actually gone? If I change the navigation backing state right away to pop a view or try and set a sheet as not to display , I‚Äôm usually presented with inconsistent UI behavior or a message saying that I‚Äôm trying to present / dismiss in an invalid state.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:42:07

*Thread Reply:* Ah, I see.

David
2022-06-09 17:42:13

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm usually stuck doing something like asyncAwait after and then playing with the timeframe and that‚Äôs, well, gross.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:42:53

*Thread Reply:* The delay hack is one approach.

David
2022-06-09 17:43:20

*Thread Reply:* Yah, and I does work for sure

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:43:28

*Thread Reply:* Another approach people seem to have some success with is using a common sheet modifier for a variety of presentations.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:43:42

*Thread Reply:* Then you can drive the sheet with an optional enum state.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:44:05

*Thread Reply:* Set it to nil to dismiss, or switch between different non-nil values to present different sheets.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:45:14

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôre also made some improvements in iOS 16 to make the invalid state issue much less common. For example, we try to delay the presentation of the next sheet until the previous one is gone. So you might find that things just work now. üôÇ

David
2022-06-09 17:45:40

UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:34:14

@David asked > Do ids in a ForEach just need to be unique within that ForEach or globally? For instance using the new Charts, all my data is keyed by date and there are several places where I have adjacent ForEaches that include mostly the same dates.

John H (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:35:06

*Thread Reply:* The IDs must be unique within the container, so for example if you have a List with two ForEach's inside it, they must generate unique IDs within that List.

ü§î David
üëç David, Chang
UIFrameworks - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 17:35:18

@Lawrence asked > I am new to SwiftUI, what is the best way to Switch between Views? For example, depending on the condition of a @State variable how can I switch between a HomeView, SignInView and SignUpView?

Carson
2022-06-09 17:37:53

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôve personally done this before with a parent ‚Äúcontainer‚Äù view, an enum to represent the different possible views, and an @State var that I use in a switch statement to swap out views. I have @Binding vars in all my child views so they can programatically change what‚Äôs shown in the parent.

However, with programatic navigation in NavigationStack that‚Äôd probably be the preferred way to do this, check out the SwiftUI cookbook for navigation session by @Curt C (Apple) for more

Apple Developer
The SwiftUI cookbook for navigation - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
The recipe for a great app begins with a clear and robust navigation structure. Join the SwiftUI team in our proverbial coding kitchen...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10054/
Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:39:03

*Thread Reply:* You can actually use switch statements directly in SwiftUI! e.g.

```enum Screen { case home case signIn case signUp }

...

@State private var selectedScreen: Screen

...

var body: some View { switch selectedScreen { case .home: HomeView() case .signIn: SignInView() case .signUp: SignUpView() } }```

‚òùÔ∏è Carson, Mahmoud, Cristian-Mihai
üôå Cristian-Mihai, Lawrence
Carson
2022-06-09 17:39:25

*Thread Reply:* Yeah that‚Äôs how I‚Äôve done it

Carson
2022-06-09 17:40:03

*Thread Reply:* But I mostly did that because I couldn‚Äôt use a NavigationStack on macOS before

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 17:41:07

*Thread Reply:* NavigationView is what I used before the new navigations were introduced.

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-09 17:52:51

*Thread Reply:* Depending on your needs, NavigationStack is also a great tool to use for this, directly manipulating the current path üëç

But if you just need to swap views in and out, a switch works just fine. For example, it‚Äôs common to use a switch to choose the detail view of a NavigationSplitView based on the current selection.
